llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Eligible primary care patients 12 to 80 years of age had impaired asthma-related quality of life (Mini Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire [MiniAQLQ] score ≤6) or inadequate asthma control (Asthma Control Questionnaire [ACQ] score ≥1)."
2. "We randomly assigned patients to 2 years of open-label therapy, under the care of their usual physician, with LTRA (148 patients) or an inhaled glucocorticoid (135 patients) as the first-line controller therapy trial and LTRA (170 patients) or LABA (182 patients) added to an inhaled glucocorticoid in the add-on therapy trial."

The trial included a broad patient population aged 12 to 80 with impaired asthma-related quality of life or inadequate asthma control. Patients were under the care of their usual physician, suggesting real-world conditions. However, the use of specific questionnaire score cutoffs for inclusion (MiniAQLQ ≤6, ACQ ≥1) is not typical of usual care and makes the trial more explanatory.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "An automated, computerized telephone center randomly assigned eligible patients at baseline to open-label treatment with either an LTRA (montelukast or zafirlukast) or an inhaled glucocorticoid (beclomethasone, budesonide, or fluticasone) in the first-line controller therapy trial and with either an LTRA or LABA (salmeterol or formoterol) together with an inhaled glucocorticoid in the add-on therapy trial."

The trial used an automated telephone system to randomly assign patients, which is not a typical recruitment method used in usual care. No other details are provided about the recruitment process.

Score: [NA]

Setting:

Relevant quotes:
1. "We conducted two parallel, multicenter, pragmatic trials to evaluate the real-world effectiveness of a leukotriene-receptor antagonist (LTRA) as compared with either an inhaled glucocorticoid for first-line asthma-controller therapy or a long-acting beta2-agonist (LABA) as add-on therapy in patients already receiving inhaled glucocorticoid therapy."

The trial was conducted in multiple centers to evaluate real-world effectiveness, suggesting a pragmatic approach. However, no other details are provided about the specific settings of these centers and how they compare to usual care.

Score: [4]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "An automated, computerized telephone center randomly assigned eligible patients at baseline to open-label treatment" [...] ""
2. "Practice staff were asked to provide each patient with a written individualized asthma-action plan. For each of the assigned treatments, choices of individual drugs and devices were made according to normal clinical practice and British asthma guidelines."

The use of an automated telephone system for randomization is not typical of usual care organization. However, the trial aimed to fit into normal clinical practice by allowing choice of individual drugs and devices according to guidelines. Overall, the organization seems to be a mix of pragmatic and explanatory elements.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "For each of the assigned treatments, choices of individual drugs and devices were made according to normal clinical practice and British asthma guidelines."
2. "The protocol discouraged substantial treatment changes between randomization and the 2-month visit. If a patient required a change in therapy during this period, this fact was noted, and the patient remained in the study."

Treatment delivery allowed flexibility in choice of individual drugs and devices according to normal practice and guidelines. However, the protocol discouraged substantial treatment changes in the first 2 months, reducing flexibility. Patients remained in the study even if changes were required.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):

No relevant quotes were found in the full text regarding measures to ensure or monitor patient adherence to the assigned treatments.

Score: [NA]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "An automated, computerized telephone center randomly assigned eligible patients at baseline to open-label treatment" [...] ""
2. "Practice staff were asked to provide each patient with a written individualized asthma-action plan."
3. "Clinical and lung-function data were recorded by clinic staff who were aware of the treatment assignments. Data collection and statistical analyses were performed by study personnel who were unaware of the treatment assignments; questionnaire-based data were collected under blinded conditions, and routine practice data (including a history of exacerbations) were extracted with the use of dedicated software."

The trial used an automated telephone system for baseline assessment, which is not typical of usual care follow-up. Individualized asthma-action plans were provided, but it's unclear if this represents an increase in follow-up intensity compared to usual care. Blinding of questionnaire-based data collection and extraction of routine practice data is a more explanatory approach.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The primary outcome measure was the MiniAQLQ score. Secondary outcome measures included the ACQ score, the score on the not-yet-validated Royal College of Physicians 3-item asthma questionnaire (RCP3) (range of scores, 0 to 3, with higher scores indicating worse asthma control), the score on the validated 14-item Mini Rhinoconjunctivitis Quality of Life Questionnaire (MiniRQLQ) (range of scores, 0 to 6, with higher scores indicating worse rhinitis-related impairment and with an MID of 0.7), and the frequency of asthma exacerbations, which were defined as the need for an oral course of glucocorticoids or hospitalization for asthma."

The primary outcome, MiniAQLQ score, is a validated patient-reported measure of asthma-related quality of life and is relevant to patients. Most secondary outcomes also assess patient-relevant factors like asthma control, rhinitis-related quality of life, and exacerbation frequency. The use of the not-yet-validated RCP3 is a more explanatory element.

Score: [4]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The primary effectiveness analysis was an intention-to-treat analysis of the MiniAQLQ score at 2 months (the primary time point) and at 2 years. Analysis of covariance was used, with treatment as a fixed effect and the baseline value as a covariate."

The trial used an intention-to-treat analysis, which is a pragmatic approach that includes all participants according to their randomized groups. Imputation was used for missing data, which is also consistent with a pragmatic approach.

Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Recruited patients (recruitment visit, −1) attended an initial 8-week outpatient-based intensive pulmonary rehabilitation programme conducted in a hospital rehabilitation department."
2. "Exclusion criteria were having a diagnosis of moderate-to-severe COPD (a Body mass index, Airflow obstruction, Dyspnoea and Exercise capacity index [BODE] index of 7–10) according to international guidelines and having been clinically stable for the previous 4 weeks (see the online supplementary material)."

The trial had fairly strict eligibility criteria, excluding patients without a confirmed moderate-to-severe COPD diagnosis based on the BODE index, and only including clinically stable patients. The initial intensive rehabilitation program was also conducted in a hospital setting, which differs from usual care for COPD patients. These factors make the eligibility criteria more explanatory than pragmatic.

Score: [2]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "This was a multicentre open-label pragmatic parallel-group randomized clinical trial was conducted. Two groups were created at completion of an 8-week intensive outpatient hospital PR programme."

The trial recruited patients from multiple centers who were completing an intensive outpatient hospital-based pulmonary rehabilitation program. While this is more pragmatic than recruiting through other means like advertisements, it still represents a more explanatory approach than recruiting directly through usual care visits.

Score: [3]

Setting:

Relevant quote: 
1. "This was a multicentre open-label pragmatic parallel-group randomized clinical trial involving 13 hospitals and was conducted between 2014 and 2017."

The trial was conducted across 13 hospitals, representing a fairly diverse range of settings. However, all the sites were hospitals rather than other care settings where COPD is routinely managed, like primary care clinics. So while the multicentre approach increases pragmatism, the hospital-only settings make it more explanatory than a true usual care approach.

Score: [3]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The hospital-based outpatient programme consisted of three training sessions a week which included 30 min of weight lifting and 30 min of leg cycle ergometry along with four educational sessions which included chest physiotherapy training (see online supplementary material)."
2. "Patients in the IG were asked to continue at home with a similar training schedule to that completed in the hospital."

The intervention required specialized staff to provide weight training, ergometry, and educational sessions that included chest physiotherapy training. Patients were also provided with training equipment like dumbbells and exercise bicycle to continue the program at home. This represents a significant increase in organizational resources compared to usual care for COPD.

Score: [2] 

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "The Intervention group (IG) patients were given appropriate training equipment and instructed to perform three weekly training sessions and send performance data through an app to a web-based platform."
2. "Patients in the CG received usual care, that is, they were advised to exercise regularly (at least walking for 1 hour a day) and provided with general educational material, following current clinical practice at participating sites."

The intervention group had a strict protocol to perform three weekly training sessions and send data through an app. In contrast, the control group had more flexibility, with general advice to exercise regularly for at least 1 hour/day. The regimented IG protocol is more explanatory, while the CG approach is more pragmatic and flexible.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):

No relevant quotes identified. The manuscript does not discuss any measures to monitor or enforce patient adherence to the intervention protocol.

Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "At each follow-up visit, patients were advised to continue doing exercise and attending follow-up appointments even if they decided not to comply with the assigned maintenance exercises, supporting the intention-to-treat principle (see online supplementary material)."
2. "After the randomization visit, follow-up appointments were arranged for both groups at 3, 9 and 12 months. At each follow-up visit, the general health status of the patient was assessed, medical treatment was revised and optimized, educational reinforcement was provided, 6-minute walk test (6MWT) and spirometry tests were carried out and HRQoL measures were taken."

The follow-up schedule of visits every 3 months is more frequent than typical COPD care. The visits also involved extensive data collection including 6MWT, spirometry, and HRQoL questionnaires that go beyond usual care. However, patients were advised to continue follow-up even if non-adherent, supporting an intent-to-treat approach. Overall, the follow-up is more explanatory than usual care, but with some pragmatic elements.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quote:
1. "The primary outcome was the change in the 6-min walk distance (6MWD) between baseline (randomization visit, 0) and 12 months later."

The 6-minute walk test measures functional exercise capacity, which is an outcome that is meaningful to COPD patients. However, it requires a standardized testing protocol and may not be routinely measured in usual COPD care. It strikes a balance between explanatory and pragmatic elements.

Score: [3]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Analysed (n = 40) Excluded from analysis (no 12 months results) (n = 5)"
2. "Analysed (n = 41) Excluded from analysis (no 12 months results) (n = 5)"

The primary analysis excluded a small number of patients (5 per group) due to missing 12-month data. This is a modified intent-to-treat approach that is slightly more explanatory than a full ITT using all randomized patients. However, the overall rate of exclusion was low.

Score: [4]

Acknowledgments

The authors would like to thank the participants involved in the trial, the nurses and rehabilitation personnel at each study site, and the editors of Ideas Need Communicating Language Services for their help with improving the use of English in the manuscript (supported by the Basque Foundation for Research and Innovation in Health [BIOEF]). They are also very grateful to the Spanish Clinical Research Network (SCReN) for its support, and especially to Ana Irasarri Lasarte (project manager) for her gracious and tenacious backing in many aspects of the trial management.

Appendix A. Supplementary Data

Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.arbres.2020.03.034.

1. "Recruited patients (recruitment visit, −1) attended an initial 8-week outpatient-based intensive pulmonary rehabilitation programme conducted in a hospital rehabilitation department."
2. "Exclusion criteria were having a diagnosis of moderate-to-severe COPD (a Body mass index, Airflow obstruction, Dyspnoea and Exercise capacity index [BODE] index of 7–10) according to international guidelines and having been clinically stable for the previous 4 weeks (see the online supplementary material)."

The trial had fairly strict eligibility criteria, excluding patients without a confirmed moderate-to-severe COPD diagnosis based on the BODE index, and only including clinically stable patients. The initial intensive rehabilitation program was also conducted in a hospital setting, which differs from usual care for COPD patients. These factors make the eligibility criteria more explanatory than pragmatic.

Score: [2]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "This was a multicentre open-label pragmatic parallel-group randomized clinical trial was conducted. Two groups were created at completion of an 8-week intensive outpatient hospital PR programme."

The trial recruited patients from multiple centers who were completing an intensive outpatient hospital-based pulmonary rehabilitation program. While this is more pragmatic than recruiting through other means like advertisements, it still represents a more explanatory approach than recruiting directly through usual care visits.

Score: [3]

Setting:

Relevant quote: 
1. "This was a multicentre open-label pragmatic parallel-group randomized clinical trial involving 13 hospitals and was conducted between 2014 and 2017."

The trial was conducted across 13 hospitals, representing a fairly diverse range of settings. However, all the sites were hospitals rather than other care settings where COPD is routinely managed, like primary care clinics. So while the multicentre approach increases pragmatism, the hospital-only settings make it more explanatory than a true usual care approach.

Score: [3]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The hospital-based outpatient programme consisted of three training sessions a week which included 30 min of weight lifting and 30 min of leg cycle ergometry along with four educational sessions which included chest physiotherapy training (see online supplementary material)."
2. "Patients in the IG were asked to continue at home with a similar training schedule to that completed in the hospital."

The intervention required specialized staff to provide weight training, ergometry, and educational sessions that included chest physiotherapy training. Patients were also provided with training equipment like dumbbells and exercise bicycle to continue the program at home. This represents a significant increase in organizational resources compared to usual care for COPD.

Score: [2] 

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "The Intervention group (IG) patients were given appropriate training equipment and instructed to perform three weekly training sessions and send performance data through an app to a web-based platform."
2. "Patients in the CG received usual care, that is, they were advised to exercise regularly (at least walking for 1 hour a day) and provided with general educational material, following current clinical practice at participating sites."

The intervention group had a strict protocol to perform three weekly training sessions and send data through an app. In contrast, the control group had more flexibility, with general advice to exercise regularly for at least 1 hour/day. The regimented IG protocol is more explanatory, while the CG approach is more pragmatic and flexible.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):

No relevant quotes identified. The manuscript does not discuss any measures to monitor or enforce patient adherence to the intervention protocol.

Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "At each follow-up visit, patients were advised to continue doing exercise and attending follow-up appointments even if they decided not to comply with the assigned maintenance exercises, supporting the intention-to-treat principle (see online supplementary material)."
2. "After the randomization visit, follow-up appointments were arranged for both groups at 3, 9 and 12 months. At each follow-up visit, the general health status of the patient was assessed, medical treatment was revised and optimized, educational reinforcement was provided, 6-minute walk test (6MWT) and spirometry tests were carried out and HRQoL measures were taken."

The follow-up schedule of visits every 3 months is more frequent than typical COPD care. The visits also involved extensive data collection including 6MWT, spirometry, and HRQoL questionnaires that go beyond usual care. However, patients were advised to continue follow-up even if non-adherent, supporting an intent-to-treat approach. Overall, the follow-up is more explanatory than usual care, but with some pragmatic elements.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quote:
1. "The primary outcome was the change in the 6-min walk distance (6MWD) between baseline (randomization visit, 0) and 12 months later."

The 6-minute walk test measures functional exercise capacity, which is an outcome that is meaningful to COPD patients. However, it requires a standardized testing protocol and may not be routinely measured in usual COPD care. It strikes a balance between explanatory and pragmatic elements.

Score: [3]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Analysed (n = 40) Excluded from analysis (no 12 months results) (n = 5)"
2. "Analysed (n = 41) Excluded from analysis (no 12 months results) (n = 5)"

The primary analysis excluded a small number of patients (5 per group) due to missing 12-month data. This is a modified intent-to-treat approach that is slightly more explanatory than a full ITT using all randomized patients. However, the overall rate of exclusion was low.

Score: [4]

Acknowledgments

The authors would like to thank the participants involved in the trial, the nurses and rehabilitation personnel at each study site, and the editors of Ideas Need Communicating Language Services for their help with improving the use of English in the manuscript (supported by the Basque Foundation for Research and Innovation in Health [BIOEF]). They are also very grateful to the Spanish Clinical Research Network (SCReN) for its support, and especially to Ana Irasarri Lasarte (project manager) for her gracious and tenacious backing in many aspects of the trial management.

Appendix A. Supplementary Data

Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.arbres.2020.03.034.

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Eighty people with Expanded Disability Status scores of 1 to 6.5 participated in this trial."
2. "Inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) diagnosed with MS in accordance with the McDonald criteria27; (2) registered at the MS outpatient clinic; (3) living in 1 of 6 selected municipalities; (4) aged 18 years or older; (5) capable of providing signed written informed consent; and (6) EDSS score between 1 and 6.5 (1 = minor disability, 6.5 = able to walk 20 m with or without a walking aid)."

The trial had fairly broad eligibility criteria, including people with a range of disability levels (EDSS 1 to 6.5) who were registered at the MS clinic and living in the selected municipalities. However, the criteria did exclude those with very mild or advanced disability. The trial aimed to include people likely to receive the intervention in usual care, but had some restrictions. 

Score: [4]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Eighty persons completed baseline testing. An electronic randomization system was conducted by a web-based system developed and administered by the Unit of Applied Clinical Research, Institute of Cancer Research and Molecular Medicine, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway"
2. "The system was stratified by EDSS scores (1–3.5 and 4–6.5) to ensure a mix of people with high and low EDSS scores in both groups, and the participants were randomly assigned to the intervention group or the control group."

Participants were recruited from those registered at the MS outpatient clinic in the selected municipalities. An electronic randomization system was used to assign participants to groups. This seems to align with how recruitment would occur in usual care for this population, using existing clinic registrations. No extra recruitment efforts are mentioned.

Score: [5]

Setting:

Relevant quote: "Assessments at all time points took place at a Norwegian hospital."

The trial was conducted at a single Norwegian hospital. While this may be the usual care setting for this intervention and population, including only a single center may somewhat limit applicability compared to a multi-center trial. However, not enough information is provided to fully judge if this single hospital setting matches the intended usual care setting.

Score: [4]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Six neurological physical therapists conducted the intervention over being trained in GroupCoreDIST for 5 days. The training included practical and theoretical training. The physical therapists received a booklet with descriptions and photos of all exercises and variations, as well as the theoretical framework for the intervention."
2. "The physical therapists had varied experience (1–25 years) and certification (2 had both a master's degree in neurological physical therapy and were clinical specialists in neurological physical therapy, 1 was a clinical specialist in neurological physical therapy, and 3 were generalists in physical therapy)."

The intervention was delivered by 6 neurological physical therapists who received 5 days of specific training in the GroupCoreDIST approach. They had varied levels of experience and certification. This represents an increase in provider expertise and training compared to usual care. However, the physical therapists seem to be existing staff, not additional providers.

Score: [3] 

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Planning the group sessions: Consider each participant's main problem and which symptoms are related to it; use the appropriate position and variations of exercises (5 variations for each of the 33 exercises, 6 exercise categories to that each participant can perform the exercises with optimal movement quality."
2. "Individual balance checkpoints and participants should perform balance challenges simultaneously at the beginning and end of each session, perceive and reflect on their own balance that day, and compare their own balance before and after each session. The physical therapist links a participant's balance challenges with the choice of exercises."

The delivery of the intervention allowed the physical therapists to tailor and individualize the exercises to each participant's specific impairments and needs. There was a focus on participant-specific adjustments rather than a strict standardized protocol. This suggests high flexibility in delivery to match individual circumstances.

Score: [5]

Flexibility (adherence):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Among the 67 persons who did not respond, 57% had EDSS scores of 0 to 3.5, 21% had EDSS scores of 4 to 7, and 22% had an unknown EDSS score."
2. "At the 18-week postintervention test, 1 person from the control group became ill and was lost to follow-up, and 3 other participants from the control group missed their assessments. At the 30-week postintervention test, 2 individuals from each group missed assessments."

The trial does not mention any strategies to monitor or enforce participant adherence, such as excluding non-adherent participants. 57% of non-responders had low disability (EDSS 0-3.5), but non-response itself did not seem to be a basis for exclusion. A few participants missed assessments but were not excluded on this basis. This suggests flexibility in adherence was allowed, as would be expected in usual care.

Score: [5]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes: 
1. "Assessments were undertaken at baseline and at weeks 7, 18, and 30. Outcomes were measured with the Trunk Impairment Scale–Norwegian Version, Mini Balance Evaluation Systems Test, and Patient Global Impression of Change–Balance."
2. "Two assessors masked with regard to group allocation carried out the assessments. The assessors had received training in the standardized test procedures, and each was trained to apply uniform scoring criteria to all the participants and to perform scoring equivalently to the other assessor."

Assessments were conducted at baseline, end of intervention (7 weeks), and at 18 and 30 weeks post-intervention. This exceeds what would be typical in usual care. The assessors were masked and specifically trained in standardized procedures. Overall, the follow-up was more intense than usual care, but not excessively so.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The TIS-NV measures dynamic sitting balance and trunk control and includes 6 test items scored from 0 to 2 or 3, with a total score from 0 to 16 (0 = severe problem)."
2. "The TIS-NV is a modified version of the original Trunk Impairment Scale, which has been validated and tested for reliability in people with MS.30 The Mini-BESTest measures dynamic balance and includes 14 test items scored from 0 to 2, with a total score from 0 to 28."

The primary outcome measures (TIS-NV and Mini-BESTest) assess dynamic sitting balance, trunk control and overall balance. These outcomes are likely to be important and relevant to people with MS. The measures have been validated in MS populations. However, the use of these specific scales and the scoring criteria may not exactly match what is typical in usual care.

Score: [4]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "One individual missed all postintervention tests, leaving 79 participants in the intention-to-treat analysis."
2. "Analyzed at all time-points (n = 39)
• Excluded from analysis due to no posttest (n = 1)"

The primary analysis was conducted as an intention-to-treat analysis, including all participants except one individual who missed all post-intervention tests. This is a pragmatic approach that includes nearly all participants in the analysis regardless of adherence. Excluding one participant with no outcome data is reasonable and unlikely to significantly impact the results.

Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "A pilot trial of at least 30 participants is adequate for obtaining estimates of the standard deviation of the outcome variable to determine sample size for an efficacy trial."
2. "Recruitment took place between December 2012 and May 2013. We administered the screening questionnaires via telephone. Inclusion criteria were diagnosis of PPMS or SPMS, Internet access and some level of distress determined by a score of 3 or greater on the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)."

The trial had relatively broad eligibility criteria, including people with primary progressive or secondary progressive MS who had some level of distress. The main exclusion criteria were cognitive impairment and lack of internet access. While these criteria are somewhat stricter than what would be used in usual care, they are not overly restrictive. The trial aimed to include a representative sample of people with progressive MS who could potentially benefit from the intervention.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Recruitment took place between December 2012 and May 2013. We administered the screening questionnaires via telephone."
2. "Inclusion criteria were diagnosis of PPMS or SPMS, Internet access and some level of distress determined by a score of 3 or greater on the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)."

Recruitment was done via telephone screening using questionnaires to assess eligibility based on MS diagnosis, internet access, and distress levels. This approach is somewhat more systematic than what would typically occur in usual care, but it is not a highly targeted or resource-intensive recruitment strategy. The recruitment period of about 6 months is reasonably representative of a real-world timeline.

Score: [4]  

Setting:

Relevant quotes:
1. "We recruited potential participants through adverts on the MS Society website and from National Health Service (NHS) MS centres across the UK."
2. "The study was approved by London City Road and Hampstead Research Ethics Committee (12/LO/1394)"

The trial recruited participants from both MS Society channels and NHS clinics across the UK, indicating that the setting has good representativeness of the real-world healthcare environment for MS in the UK. The trial was approved by a research ethics committee, as would be expected for a trial in this setting. Overall, the setting appears to be a good match to where the intervention would be applied in practice.

Score: [5]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "We adapted these cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) techniques so that instead of exploring how thoughts and feelings are linked and how this can lead to low mood, we discussed thoughts regarding having MS and how these thoughts are linked to anxiety and low mood."
2. "Teaching standards and teacher competence are important in mindfulness especially when working with vulnerable groups.23 AB, a health psychologist, facilitated the courses. AB was supervised by PC, a clinical psychologist and expert mindfulness practitioner. AB and PC met weekly, and PC listened to excerpts of each and every session for supervision and fidelity purposes."

The intervention used standard CBT techniques adapted for people with MS, and was delivered by a health psychologist with supervision from a clinical psychologist with mindfulness expertise. The organization of the intervention delivery appears to be feasible within existing healthcare resources, without requiring substantial additional training or changes to typical care delivery. Some extra resources were used for supervision and fidelity monitoring, but these do not seem excessive for an intervention study.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes: 
1. "The eight chapters, one for each session, introduced key mindfulness concepts, addressed issues common to progressive MS and described homework for the week ahead (see online supplementary material for content of each session)."
2. "Participants allocated to the waiting-list group received the treatment as usual (TAU) and were offered the mindfulness course after the end of the controlled trial, and completed the intervention and assessments."

The intervention followed a structured 8-session format with defined content for each session. However, the content was specifically adapted for people with progressive MS. The waiting-list control group received usual care. This indicates a moderately flexible delivery, with a general framework but some tailoring to the MS population. It is not a highly rigid, protocol-driven intervention, but also not as flexible as usual care.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Fifty participants were recruited and completed baseline questionnaires. Of these, 19 (38%) participants were lost to follow-up."
2. "In the mindfulness group, two participants (10.5%) did not complete the post-therapy and three-month follow-up assessments."

The study had a relatively high loss to follow-up rate of 38% overall. In the intervention group specifically, 10.5% did not complete the post-treatment assessments. However, there is no indication of any additional procedures to monitor or enforce adherence during the study beyond what would occur in usual care. Participants were allowed flexibility in completing assessments.

Score: [4]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants completed standardised questionnaires to measure mood, impact of MS and symptom severity, quality of life and service costs at baseline, post-intervention and three-month follow-up."
2. "Fifty participants were recruited and completed baseline questionnaires. Of these, 19 (38%) participants were lost to follow-up."

Participants completed questionnaires at baseline, post-intervention, and 3-month follow-up. This schedule is somewhat more intensive than typical usual care, but not excessively burdensome. A 3-month follow-up is a reasonable time frame for assessing meaningful outcomes. However, the high loss to follow-up rate of 38% suggests that the follow-up procedures may have been challenging for many participants to complete.

Score: [3] 

Primary outcome:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The GHQ27 is designed to measure general levels of distress. The GHQ is uncontaminated by the experience of MS-related somatic symptoms and is the most treatment-responsive measure of psychological distress in MS.26 Higher scores on this scale represent high distress."
2. "Secondary outcomes were estimated using linear mixed modelling where the outcome variables at the two post-intervention time points are the dependent variable."

The primary outcome was the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ) score, which measures general psychological distress and has been validated in MS populations as a responsive measure. This appears to be an outcome that is relevant and meaningful to patients. Secondary outcomes included measures of MS-specific constructs like disability, impact of MS, anxiety, depression, quality of life, and service costs. These all seem to be important outcomes from a patient perspective.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Of the 40 randomised participants, 17 (42%) had PPMS, and 23 (57.5%) had SPMS. The overall sample was 55% female, predominantly white British (90%), with a mean age of 52.7 years (SD = 9.5), with the majority married or cohabiting (77.5%)."
2. "Treatment effects on the primary and secondary outcomes were estimated using an intention-to-treat analysis where we analysed participants in the group to which they were randomised."

The primary analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, including all randomized participants based on their assigned groups. This is a pragmatic approach that preserves the benefits of randomization and provides a realistic estimate of average treatment effects. No mention is made of excluding any participants from the primary analysis. Baseline characteristics are reported for the full randomized sample.

Score: [5]
original_llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "A pilot trial of at least 30 participants is adequate for obtaining estimates of the standard deviation of the outcome variable to determine sample size for an efficacy trial."
2. "Recruitment took place between December 2012 and May 2013. We administered the screening questionnaires via telephone. Inclusion criteria were diagnosis of PPMS or SPMS, Internet access and some level of distress determined by a score of 3 or greater on the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)."

The trial had relatively broad eligibility criteria, including people with primary progressive or secondary progressive MS who had some level of distress. The main exclusion criteria were cognitive impairment and lack of internet access. While these criteria are somewhat stricter than what would be used in usual care, they are not overly restrictive. The trial aimed to include a representative sample of people with progressive MS who could potentially benefit from the intervention.

2. "Inclusion criteria were diagnosis of PPMS or SPMS, Internet access and some level of distress determined by a score of 3 or greater on the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)."

The recruitment period of about 6 months is reasonably representative of a real-world timeline.

Score: [5]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "We adapted these cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) techniques so that instead of exploring how thoughts and feelings are linked and how this can lead to low mood, we discussed thoughts regarding having MS and how these thoughts are linked to anxiety and low mood."
2. "Teaching standards and teacher competence are important in mindfulness especially when working with vulnerable groups.23 AB, a health psychologist, facilitated the courses. AB was supervised by PC, a clinical psychologist and expert mindfulness practitioner. AB and PC met weekly, and PC listened to excerpts of each and every session for supervision and fidelity purposes."

The intervention used standard CBT techniques adapted for people with MS, and was delivered by a health psychologist with supervision from a clinical psychologist with mindfulness expertise. The organization of the intervention delivery appears to be feasible within existing healthcare resources, without requiring substantial additional training or changes to typical care delivery. Some extra resources were used for supervision and fidelity monitoring, but these do not seem excessive for an intervention study.

The intervention followed a structured 8-session format with defined content for each session. However, the content was specifically adapted for people with progressive MS. The waiting-list control group received usual care. This indicates a moderately flexible delivery, with a general framework but some tailoring to the MS population. It is not a highly rigid, protocol-driven intervention, but also not as flexible as usual care.

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The inclusion criteria were as follows: age > 18, confirmed diagnosis of MS, Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score 2.0–6.5, Six Spot Step Test (SSST) score > 8 seconds or Timed 25-Foot Walk (T25FW) > 5 seconds, relapse-free within the past 8 weeks, and no change in disease-modifying medication or medication that affects gait performance and spasticity within the past 8 weeks."
2. "Exclusion criteria were as follows: inability to walk, spasticity level O=0 in terms of cognitive disorders or alcohol abuse (based on clinical judgment), pathologies that did not allow systematic PRT and BMCT and PRT for at least 3 months."

The trial had fairly strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, including specific EDSS and walking test scores, being relapse-free and on stable medications, and excluding those unable to walk or with certain comorbidities. While some criteria like confirmed MS diagnosis and ability to walk would be typical in usual care, others like EDSS and SSST scores are more restrictive than the general MS population. The criteria overall seem to select a somewhat narrower population than all MS patients likely to receive the intervention in usual care.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:

The full text does not provide any information on how participants were recruited for the trial.

Score: [NA]

Setting:

Relevant quote: "Groups of 3–6 patients were referred to physiotherapy clinics that were randomly assigned to provide either PRT or BMCT or to a waitlist CON. Allocation of interventions was done by a cluster randomization conducted whenever groups could be established at three different participating clinics."

The trial was conducted at multiple physiotherapy clinics, to which participants were referred. This appears to be a setting very similar to where the intervention would be delivered in usual care. Conducting the trial at multiple sites, rather than a single center, also supports generalizability.

Score: [5]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Allocation of interventions was done by a cluster randomization conducted whenever groups could be established at three different participating clinics."
2. "A research assistant (L.A.) assigned patients with an ID number and pseudonyms, which were used during baseline and follow-up assessments."

The trial used a cluster randomization by clinic, suggesting the intervention was delivered by usual staff at the clinics rather than by specialized trial personnel. Assessments were done by a research assistant, but it's unclear if this person was part of the usual care staff. Overall, the organization appears largely similar to usual care, with the possible exception of the research assistant's involvement.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "PRT PRT consisted of 21-hour training sessions over 10 weeks (two sessions/week). Each session started with a 10-minute warm-up on a stationary bicycle or treadmill. The program predominantly targeted knee and hip flexion and extension where the exercises progressed from three sets of 10 repetitions at 15 RM toward four sets of 8 repetitions at 8 RM (Table 1)."
2. "BMCT The BMCT intervention consisted of 20 1-hour training sessions over 10 weeks (two sessions/ week). All sessions started with a 10-minute warm-up on a stationary bicycle or treadmill."

The PRT and BMCT interventions followed a defined protocol in terms of overall duration, frequency, and session content. However, some flexibility was allowed in the specific exercises performed and in progressing load based on individual capacity. On balance, the delivery appears to be somewhat protocol-driven but with a moderate degree of flexibility.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Two adverse events occurred in the PRT group. One participant experienced exacerbation of fatigue following PRT sessions and dropped out; one experienced intermittent low back pain during PRT, but continued in the study."
2. "Of particular interest is the finding of an increase in gait speed from BMCT despite no change in strength compared to CON. However, the increase in maximal gait speed in PRT (0.06 m/s) on the T25FW was also not significant when compared to CON."

The text mentions two adverse events in the PRT group, one of which led to dropout. However, it does not specify any measures to monitor or enforce participant adherence, or any thresholds for dropping non-adherent participants. The analysis appears to include all participants, suggesting an intent-to-treat approach with respect to adherence. Overall, there is insufficient information to determine how closely adherence was monitored or enforced.

Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:

Relevant quote: "Participants were included from September 2016 to October 2018, after being invited via seven MS clinics (specified in "Acknowledgements" section) and targeted advertisements sent out via the Danish MS Society."

The text does not provide details on the frequency or duration of follow-up visits, or how these compared to usual care. It also does not specify the duration of the trial from a participant perspective. There is insufficient information to assess the follow-up burden compared to usual care.

Score: [NA]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quotes: 
1. "The primary outcomes were walking speed assessed by the T25FW20 and complex walking assessed by the SSST.21"
2. "Walking devices were allowed, but ankle foot orthotics or nerve-stimulating devices were detached."

The primary outcomes were two measures of walking performance - the Timed 25-Foot Walk and Six Spot Step Test. Walking speed and complex walking ability are outcomes that are directly relevant and meaningful to MS patients. The tests appear to have been conducted in a manner very similar to usual care, allowing walking aids but removing orthotics and nerve stimulators. This suggests the outcomes assessment mimicked real-world conditions.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quote: "Analyses were carried out as intention-to-treat, where all participants were included regardless of their adherence to the allocated intervention. Carry forward imputations were not used to replace missing data in the primary intention to treat analysis."

The primary analysis was conducted as intention-to-treat, including all participants regardless of adherence. No methods were used to impute missing data. This suggests a very pragmatic approach to the analysis, using all available data without any post-randomization exclusions.

Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "A total of 120 PwMS were recruited via the Sheffield MS Clinic and flyers/community adverts displayed at the local South Yorkshire MS Society branches. All patients were assessed by a consultant neurologist with an interest in MS prior to entering the trial. The inclusion criteria for the trial were clinical diagnosis of MS, as defined by the modified McDonald criteria, with an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score of 1.0–6.5, and able to walk a 10-metre distance; aged 18–65 years; clinically stable for at least four weeks prior to entering the study; physically able to participate in exercise three times per week; able to provide written informed consent."

The trial recruited participants from MS clinics and community advertisements, assessing them based on standard clinical criteria like MS diagnosis, EDSS score, age, clinical stability, physical ability to exercise, and ability to provide consent. While these criteria would be used in usual care, the EDSS score range of 1.0-6.5 and age range of 18-65 are narrower than the full spectrum of MS patients likely to be treated in usual care. The physical ability and consent requirements may also exclude some patients compared to usual care.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "A total of 120 PwMS were recruited via the Sheffield MS Clinic and flyers/community adverts displayed at the local South Yorkshire MS Society branches."

Participants were recruited from a single MS clinic and through community advertisements and patient society branches in one region. While recruiting from an MS clinic is pragmatic, using flyers and community advertisements is an extra recruitment effort that goes beyond what would occur in usual care. Limiting to one region also reduces generalizability compared to recruiting from multiple centers.

Score: [3] 

Setting:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants on disease-modifying therapy (interferon beta, glatiramer acetate and natalizumab) had been stable on this treatment for at least three months."
2. "Participants were encouraged to exercise in community-based settings."

The trial was conducted in community-based settings, which matches where most MS patients would receive an exercise intervention in usual care. However, participants were recruited from a single MS clinic, so the setting is not as broad as all the centers that would treat MS patients in usual care. Participants were also required to be on stable disease-modifying therapy, which may differ from the full spectrum treated in usual practice.

Score: [4]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "An exercise physiologist supervised the delivery of the intervention but with physiotherapist input during the early stages of the programme. During weeks 1–6, participants attended two supervised sessions per week at a university exercise research facility and engaged in one additional self-directed exercise session in their home or local community."

The intervention was delivered by an exercise physiologist with some physiotherapist input, which is likely a higher level of expertise than would be consistently available in usual care. The sessions were held in a university research facility, which differs from typical community settings. Participants did complete some self-directed sessions at home or in the community, but the overall organization of the intervention included extra resources.

Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Supervised exercise sessions involved up to three participants and lasted for approximately one hour. Studies show that aerobic exercise, resistance exercise and combined programmes bring health benefits to PwMS. Hence, the programme was designed to be pragmatic and accessible, taking into account exercise preferences and giving choices."
2. "Aerobic exercise was the core component and was accessible (i.e. includes community-based walking exercise) and does not require equipment."

The intervention involved supervised group sessions of aerobic exercise, resistance training, and combined training, allowing some choice of exercise type based on patient preference. The aerobic component was designed to be accessible in community settings without equipment. This represents a moderately flexible approach that is mostly pragmatic but somewhat more structured than usual care.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Adherence to the supervised and home-exercise sessions was very good, with participants attending an average of 16.2 of the 18 supervised sessions (90%; range 7–18 sessions) and participating in an average of 14.6 of the 18 prescribed home-exercise sessions (81%, range 2–18 sessions). Home exercise during the intervention period comprised walking."

Adherence to the intervention was encouraged but very good adherence was not required. Participants attended an average of 90% of supervised sessions and 81% of home sessions, with wide ranges, suggesting that perfect adherence was not mandated. No adherence-based exclusions were reported. This represents a pragmatic approach, applying no more than usual encouragement for adherence.

Score: [5]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants were followed up to nine months after recruitment."
2. "An additional period of follow-up in comparison with participants randomised to usual care alone, full details of the protocol have been published previously."

Participants were followed for 9 months after recruitment, which is longer than typical follow-up for an exercise intervention in usual care. The trial also collected more extensive data than usual, as indicated by the published protocol. However, the follow-up did not involve any additional treatment or interaction with participants beyond data collection.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Objective: The objective of this study was to assess the effects of a practically implemented exercise programme on self-directed exercise behaviour and important health outcomes in PwMS to nine months of follow-up."
2. "Primary outcome was self-reported exercise behaviour at three months using the Godin Leisure Time Exercise Questionnaire (GLTEQ)."

The primary outcome of self-reported exercise behavior at 3 months using the GLTEQ is relevant to participants, as increasing self-directed exercise is a patient-centered goal. However, using a self-report questionnaire is less direct than measuring actual exercise behavior. The 3-month time point is also a relatively short-term outcome.

Score: [4]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants who were lost to follow-up at three months were treated as non-exercisers and included in the analysis."

The primary analysis took a pragmatic approach by including all participants lost to follow-up at 3 months, treating them as non-exercisers rather than excluding them. This is similar to an intention-to-treat approach. No other details are provided on the analysis methods.

Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants with a diagnosis of MS and clinical levels of depression were recruited through out-patient clinics and postal screening questionnaires at two UK centres and randomised to CCBT or usual care."
2. "Exclusion criteria were: poor English language skills or cognitive function (score of less than 24 on Mini Mental State Examination [20]); BDI score of at least 29 on two consecutive occasions; active suicidal ideas; current or life-time diagnosis of psychosis, organic mental disorder or addictive disorder; Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score of 8.5 or above [21])."

The trial recruited participants with MS and depression from out-patient clinics and postal screening, which is fairly pragmatic. However, there were several exclusion criteria that would not be applied in usual care, such as excluding those with poor English skills, low cognitive function, very severe depression (BDI ≥29), psychosis, and high disability (EDSS ≥8.5). These criteria likely excluded some patients who would have received the intervention in usual care.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants with a diagnosis of MS and clinical levels of depression were recruited through out-patient clinics and postal screening questionnaires at two UK centres and randomised to CCBT or usual care."

Participants were recruited through out-patient clinics and postal screening questionnaires, which is a fairly pragmatic approach that does not differ substantially from usual care. No extra effort beyond what would be done in usual care seems to have been made.

Score: [4]

Setting:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants with a diagnosis of MS and clinical levels of depression were recruited through out-patient clinics and postal screening questionnaires at two UK centres and randomised to CCBT or usual care."

The trial was conducted at two UK centers and recruited from out-patient clinics, which appears to be the same setting as where usual care would be provided. This represents a pragmatic choice of setting.

Score: [5]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The CCBT service provided to trial participants was the routine service provided by the Sheffield Care Trust."
2. "Delivery of CCBT (home/external) and variation in delivery and use In the Sheffield region, Primary Care Trust (PCT) mental health care teams administered the CCBT, facilitating access and undertaking safety monitoring (PCTs were publicly funded organisations responsible for commissioning acute services for local populations). The CCBT service provided to trial participants was the routine"

The trial used the routine CCBT service provided by the Sheffield Care Trust, delivered by the usual publicly funded mental health care teams. This organization appears identical to usual care.

Score: [5]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "A client service receipt inventory was used at baseline, 8 weeks to identify concomitant medication and service use in both arms: the research protocol did not manualise or restrict treatment as usual."

The research protocol did not restrict or manualise the treatment as usual in both arms, allowing flexibility in delivery. This suggests a very pragmatic approach.

Score: [5]

Flexibility (adherence):

There are no relevant quotes about measures to ensure or monitor participant adherence to the intervention. The flexibility of adherence appears to be the same as in usual care.

Score: [5]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The pre-specified primary outcome was the recruitment rate, calculated as the proportion of those invited to fill in a screening questionnaire who entered the trial."
2. "A short semi-structured telephone interview was conducted with all study participants on completion of CCBT during which they were asked how they felt about the processes of recruitment and randomisation, the location of CCBT, their reasons for dropping out or not completing (where appropriate) and the appropriateness of the quantitative outcome measures used in the study."

The primary outcome was recruitment rate, calculated in a way that is not typical in usual care. Participants also completed semi-structured interviews about their experiences in the trial. This represents a more intensive follow-up than would be expected in usual care.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quote:
1. "The pre-specified primary outcome was the recruitment rate, calculated as the proportion of those invited to fill in a screening questionnaire who entered the trial."

The primary outcome of recruitment rate is not directly relevant to patients and would not be assessed in usual care. It is more of interest to researchers than to participants.

Score: [2]

Primary analysis:

There are no relevant quotes about the primary analysis method. Not enough information is provided to determine if the analysis included all randomized participants in their original groups (intention-to-treat) or used a more explanatory approach.

Score: [NA]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
1. "Key inclusion criteria permitted the participation of men or women ≥18 years of age with confirmed RRMS (diagnosed using the revised McDonald criteria) (Polman et al., 2011), Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score of 0 to 5.5 at the screening visit, and, for women of childbearing, a stable neurological condition, relapse-free status, and no use of any corticosteroid or adrenocorticotropic hormone treatment."
2. "Key exclusion criteria were previous exposure to GA40, a progressive form of MS or neuromyelitis optica, the use of experimental or investigational drugs, participation in clinical drug studies within the 6 months before screening, recent use of immunosuppressive medications (other than systemic corticosteroids), antibiotics, or vaccines use of alemtuzumab, cladribine, cyclophosphamide, or mitoxantrone."

The trial had fairly standard inclusion/exclusion criteria for an RRMS population, allowing a broad range of patients to participate. However, some criteria like EDSS score ≤5.5 and relapse-free/stable condition would exclude more severe or active RRMS patients that may still be treated with GA40 in usual care. The exclusion of patients with prior GA40 exposure or recent use of other MS drugs is also stricter than usual care. Overall, the eligibility criteria were moderately pragmatic but had some explanatory elements.
Score: [3]

Recruitment:
The full text does not provide any details on the recruitment methods used in this trial.
Score: [NA] 

Setting:
Quotes:
1. "The CONFIDENCE study was a multinational, multicenter, randomized, parallel-group, phase 4, open-label study conducted at 88 study centers in 14 countries (Russia, Poland, Italy, France, Croatia, US [including Puerto Rico], Mexico, Spain, Austria, Turkey, Belgium, Argentina, Germany, and Finland) across different geographic regions."

The trial was conducted at 88 centers across 14 countries in different geographic regions. This matches the settings where GA40 would be used as a treatment for RRMS in usual care. Conducting the trial at both specialist and general centers internationally gives the results broad applicability.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes:
1. "Patients were randomized to GA40 or GA20 and received allocated intervention (n=430, safety population; n=428, full analysis set)."

The trial mentions patients being randomized to receive either GA40 or GA20, but does not describe any additional organizational resources used to deliver the intervention beyond what would be available in usual care. Administering GA40 and GA20 appears to have been done in line with routine practices.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
The full text does not provide any details on the flexibility of intervention delivery in this trial. 
Score: [NA]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: 
1. "Patients withdrawn (n=32) Death (n=1) Adverse event (n=14) Withdrawal by patient (n=10) Protocol violation (n=1) Lost to follow-up (n=2) Other (n=4)"

The information on patient withdrawals suggests that continued participation was not strictly enforced, as patients withdrew for various reasons including adverse events, patient choice, and loss to follow-up. This represents a pragmatic approach without any apparent measures to ensure adherence.
Score: [4]

Follow-up:
Quotes:
1. "Patients' adherence to treatment measured at Months 1, 3, and 6 using the MS-TAQ questionnaire showed consistently greater adherence to treatment in patients receiving GA40 compared with those receiving GA20 (Fig. 5). RM ANOVA analyses of MS-TAQ total scores during the 6-month treatment period showed significantly lower MS-TAQ scores in patients treated with GA40 than with GA20 during that time, indicating higher adherence to GA40 versus GA20 (table e-4)."

Patients' adherence was measured using the MS-TAQ questionnaire at Months 1, 3 and 6. This goes beyond the follow-up that would typically occur in usual care for RRMS patients on GA therapy. The use of this questionnaire at multiple timepoints to assess adherence represents a more explanatory approach to follow-up.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
1. "The overall treatment-emergent adverse event (TEAE) profile in both treatment groups was consistent with previous findings (Wolinsky et al., 2015) (Table 2). A significantly lower percentage of patients in the GA40 cohort (8.6%) reported injection-site pruritus than those in the GA20 group (13.6%, p = 0.023)."
2. "The CONFIDENCE study was designed to assess the potential advantages of a less frequently administered (GA40) versus a more frequently administered (GA20) formulation of glatiramer acetate. The question of interest between the GA40 and GA20 formulations has been evaluated in previous trials designed for that purpose (Khan et al., 2013; Zivadinov et al., 2018, 2015)."

The primary outcome was the overall TEAE profile, with a specific focus on comparing injection-site adverse events between GA40 and GA20. While safety and tolerability outcomes are important to patients, the choice to look specifically at injection-site reactions as a key outcome makes the trial more explanatory. The authors note this question has been evaluated in previous explanatory trials. An outcome of more direct clinical relevance to patients, such as relapse rates or disability progression, would have made the trial more pragmatic.
Score: [2]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
1. "A total of 876 patients were screened for eligibility, and 861 were randomly assigned to receive GA40 (n = 431) or GA20 (n = 430). In the GA40 group, 430 patients received the treatment and were included in the safety analysis set, and 428 patients were included in the FAS. In the GA20 group, 427 patients received the treatment and were included in the safety analysis set and FAS (Fig. 1). A total of 794 (92%) patients completed the core phase with similar percentages of completers in each group (92.6% [399/431] in GA40 and 91.9% [395/430] in GA20, p = 0.695)."

The primary analysis appears to be an intention-to-treat analysis using all randomized patients (the full analysis set or FAS). 92% of patients completed the trial with similar percentages of completers in each group. No adjustments seem to have been made for protocol deviations. This represents a pragmatic approach to the primary analysis.
Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants were recruited through a statewide organization providing education and support to people with MS, and a large specialist MS outpatient clinic."
2. "To be included, people had to be aged 18 years or more, have a confirmed diagnosis of relapsing–remitting MS, have an Ambulation Index score19 of 2, 3 or 4 (mild to moderate walking disabilities), and have received medical clearance to participate."

The trial recruited participants through an MS support organization and specialist clinic, and had relatively broad inclusion criteria requiring only a diagnosis of relapsing-remitting MS, mild to moderate disability based on a standard scale, and medical clearance. This suggests the participants were fairly representative of the real-world population with relapsing-remitting MS and some walking impairment. However, the Ambulation Index score cutoff of 2-4 would exclude those with very mild or more severe walking disability who may still be treated in usual care.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants were recruited through a statewide organization providing education and support to people with MS, and a large specialist MS outpatient clinic."

Participants were recruited through a state-level MS organization and a specialist MS clinic. This represents a pragmatic approach leveraging existing channels that reach the target population in the real world. However, recruitment was not done fully through usual care visits. Some additional effort was likely required beyond routine care.

Score: [4]

Setting:

Relevant quotes:
1. "To determine the effectiveness of PRT for people with MS, focusing on improving the gait deficits common in this population."
2. "Participants were recruited through a statewide organization providing education and support to people with MS, and a large specialist MS outpatient clinic."

The trial aimed to determine effectiveness of the intervention for people with MS in general, not just a single center. Participants were recruited from a state-level organization and specialist clinic, not a single center. This suggests the setting was intended to broadly represent where the target population is routinely treated. However, details are lacking on the number and specific nature of settings involved.

Score: [4]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The experimental group completed a 10-week (two times per week), PRT program in one of four community gymnasiums in metropolitan and regional areas."
2. "The exercises targeted the key lower limb muscles for supporting body weight and for generating and absorbing power during walking (Table 1)."

The intervention was delivered in typical community gyms in both metropolitan and regional areas, by exercise trainers, without mentioning additional resources or expertise beyond what would be available in usual care. The exercises targeted key muscle groups for walking using standard equipment described in Table 1. This suggests the organization of intervention delivery matched closely with what would be available in usual care.

Score: [5]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "All exercises were completed on weight machines. The training intensity was based on recommendations of the American College of Sports Medicine (2009)7 and consisted of two sets of 10–12 repetitions of each exercise, at a training intensity of 10–12 repetition maximum (that is, only 12 consecutive repetitions of each exercise could be completed before muscle fatigue was reached). The weight lifted was increased when two sets of 12 repetitions of an exercise could be completed."

The intervention used a highly specified protocol, with specific exercises, weight machines, numbers of repetitions and sets, and a defined method for progressing the intensity based on number of repetitions completed. This suggests a very explanatory approach with little flexibility in delivery compared to usual care.

Score: [2]  

Flexibility (adherence):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants attended 92% of training sessions, with no serious adverse events."
2. "At 10 weeks, no differences were detected in walking performance. However, compared with the comparison group PRT demonstrated increased leg press strength (16.8%, SD 4.5), increased reverse leg press strength (29.8%, SD 12.7), and increased muscle endurance of the reverse leg press (38.7%, SD 32.8)."

The text does not provide details on measures to enforce or monitor participant adherence, or any consequences of non-adherence. The 92% attendance rate suggests adherence was high, but it is unclear if this was due to enforced adherence strategies or natural motivation. The lack of differences in walking performance at 10 weeks despite strength gains also hints that adherence to the walking program may have been uncontrolled. Overall there is insufficient information to determine how pragmatic or explanatory the approach to adherence was.

Score: [NA]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Using a single blind randomized controlled trial, people with relapsing–remitting MS were randomly allocated to either a PRT program targeting the lower limb muscles twice a week for 10 weeks (n = 36), or usual care plus attention and social program conducted once a week for 10 weeks (n = 35). Outcomes were recorded at baseline, week 10 and week 22."

Follow-up assessments were conducted at 10 weeks (end of intervention) and 22 weeks. This schedule exceeds what would be typical in usual care. However, the 22-week follow-up allows assessing maintenance of effects, which is relevant for a progressive condition like MS. No other details are provided about the follow-up procedures and how they compare to usual care.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quotes: 
1. "Objective: To determine the effectiveness of PRT for people with MS, focusing on improving the gait deficits common in this population."
2. "Changes in walking endurance were measured with the 2MWT."

The primary aim was to evaluate effects on walking, which is an outcome that matters to patients. Walking endurance was measured with the 2-minute walk test, which is a standardized and objective test, but it may not be routinely used in usual care. The other walking outcomes like walking speed were measured using more explanatory methods like the GAITRite electronic walkway. 

Score: [3]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Intention-to-treat analysis was applied, with all participants who were allocated and commenced their program included in analysis."
2. "Where data were missing, the carry forward technique was used."

The primary analysis was intention-to-treat including all randomized participants. Missing data was handled with last observation carried forward, which is a simple but potentially biased approach. The article does not mention any additional explanatory analyses that excluded participants based on adherence or protocol deviations. This suggests a fairly pragmatic approach to analysis, but with a suboptimal missing data method.

Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Relevant quotes:
1. "Clients were provided with information about the clinic by the local chapter of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, and self selected on that basis."
2. "Of the fifteen study participants, all had previously received a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, and multiple sclerosis was confirmed for three to forty-one years (with a mean of 19 years) at the time of the study."

The study participants were self-selected clients from a multiple sclerosis clinic who had a confirmed diagnosis of MS. While some pragmatic elements are present like recruiting from a real-world clinic population, the participants were a subset of MS patients (having had MS for a mean of 19 years) rather than a fully representative sample. The self-selection aspect also makes the approach somewhat explanatory.
Score: [3]

Recruitment:
Relevant quotes:
1. "Clients were provided with information about the clinic by the local chapter of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, and self selected on that basis."

Recruitment was done by providing information through a local MS Society chapter, and interested clients self-selected to participate. This approach has some pragmatic elements by recruiting from a real-world patient pool, but the involvement of the MS Society and the self-selection aspect lean more explanatory than recruiting directly from the clinic population.
Score: [3]

Setting:
Relevant quote:
1. "Participants were clients seen in the multiple sclerosis clinics at Sutherland-Chan School, in which the study was conducted."

The trial was conducted in a real-world MS clinic setting, which is a pragmatic choice. However, it's unclear if this single clinic is representative of the range of settings MS patients typically receive care in. More information is needed to fully assess the setting's match to usual care.
Score: [4]

Organization:
No specific information is provided in the text on the resources, expertise or organization of care in the intervention arm vs usual care. There is insufficient information to score this domain.
Score: [NA] 

Flexibility (delivery):
No quotes or information are provided on the flexibility of intervention delivery compared to usual care. The full text lacks sufficient details to assess this domain.
Score: [NA]

Flexibility (adherence):
Relevant quote:
1. "Neither treatment nor control groups received massage therapy for the follow up period of eight weeks. At this point the study was concluded and the control group received treatment twice a week during the eight week post study period."

After the main 8-week treatment period, the control group then received the massage therapy intervention. This suggests flexibility in adherence was quite limited during the main trial period. However, not enough information is provided on adherence monitoring or any inclusion/exclusion criteria related to adherence to fully assess this domain.
Score: [2] 

Follow-up:
Relevant quotes:
1. "The MSSE survey was originally developed and validated by Schwartz et al. (1996), based on the work of Lorig et al. (1989), who created a similar tool for use with people suffering from arthritis."
2. "The outcome measures for the current research were the scores yielded by the Multiple Sclerosis Self Efficacy (MSSE) survey. For both treatment and control groups, self-efficacy scores were obtained before the first treatment, mid-treatment series, after the last treatment in the series, four weeks after the final treatment and again eight weeks after the final treatment had been received."

Follow-up in this study involved a validated self-efficacy survey administered at 5 timepoints, including 4 and 8 weeks after the intervention. This is more frequent and extensive data collection than would likely occur in usual care. The use of a survey tool not routinely used in usual MS care also suggests a more explanatory approach to follow-up.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Relevant quotes: 
1. "The outcome measures for the current research were the scores yielded by the Multiple Sclerosis Self Efficacy (MSSE) survey."
2. "The MSSE survey was originally developed and validated by Schwartz et al. (1996), based on the work of Lorig et al. (1989), who created a similar tool for use with people suffering from arthritis."

The primary outcome was self-efficacy as measured by the Multiple Sclerosis Self Efficacy (MSSE) survey. While self-efficacy is likely an important outcome to MS patients, the MSSE appears to be a research survey tool not widely used in routine MS care. Measuring self-efficacy with this specialized instrument is a more explanatory than pragmatic approach.

Primary analysis:
No specific information is provided in the full text on the extent to which all data was included in the primary analysis. There are insufficient details to determine if the analysis was more explanatory (e.g. per protocol) vs pragmatic (e.g. intention-to-treat).
