llm_message:
Eligibility:
Relevant quotes:
"Fifty patients with relapsing MS, followed at the Jacobs MS Center for Treatment and Research, Department of Neurology, University at Buffalo, Buffalo New York, USA, were enrolled in this study. Inclusion criteria consisted of: a diagnosis of relapsing MS according to McDonald criteria, being on natalizumab therapy for 24 months or longer, aged between 18 and 65 years and an EDSS score of ≤7.0."
"Candidates were excluded from the study if active disease was identified at baseline per clinical (presence of a relapse during the previous 30 days) and/or MRI evaluation (active gadolinium (Gd)-enhancing lesions)."

The trial had fairly strict eligibility criteria, including requiring a confirmed diagnosis of relapsing MS, being on natalizumab for at least 24 months, having an EDSS score ≤7.0, and not having active disease at baseline. These criteria are more restrictive than the typical MS population that would receive natalizumab in usual care. However, some criteria like the diagnosis of relapsing MS and use of natalizumab are still in line with the trial's target population.
Score: [2]

Recruitment:
Relevant quotes:
"Fifty patients with relapsing MS, followed at the Jacobs MS Center for Treatment and Research, Department of Neurology, University at Buffalo, Buffalo New York, USA, were enrolled in this study."

All patients were recruited from a single MS center, rather than from multiple centers or community clinics as would be more representative of usual care. This limits the generalizability of the trial results.
Score: [2] 

Setting:
Relevant quote:
"Fifty patients with relapsing MS, followed at the Jacobs MS Center for Treatment and Research, Department of Neurology, University at Buffalo, Buffalo New York, USA, were enrolled in this study."

The trial was conducted at a single academic MS center in the USA. This is a more specialized setting than the mix of community and academic centers that would manage and prescribe natalizumab for MS patients in usual care.
Score: [2]

Organization:
The full text does not provide sufficient details on the provider expertise or healthcare resources used to deliver the intervention, compared to what would be available in usual care. 
Score: [NA]

Flexibility (delivery):
Relevant quotes:
"IDG: Patients who discontinued natalizumab therapy at once and initiated another DMT (interferon, GA therapy or an oral DMT: fingolimod, dimethyl fumarate or teriflunomide) at 1–6 months following the last natalizumab infusion (1–2 months for the injectable DMTs and 3–6 months for the oral DMTs) and tapered group (TG): patients administered two additional natalizumab infusions, one at 6 weeks and one at 8 weeks (14 weeks from study entry)."

The trial protocol specified the timing and type of DMTs permitted after natalizumab discontinuation. This is a more rigid, less flexible approach than would be likely in usual care, where the choice and timing of switching to another DMT would be left up to the clinician's discretion based on the individual patient's situation.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (adherence):
The full text does not mention any measures to monitor or enforce patient adherence to the assigned intervention protocol. Adherence does not appear to be a major issue though, since the interventions mainly involved the timing of DMT administration by clinicians.
Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:
Relevant quotes:
"Clinical assessments were performed at baseline, 3, 6 and 12 months postdiscontinuation (counted from the last natalizumab infusion, as per protocol)."
"A physical examination and neurological assessment was administered at baseline, 3, 6 and 12 months postdiscontinuation (counted from the last natalizumab infusion, as per the unscheduled visits due to relapses (within 3–5 days of any new symptom development)."
"Standardised MRI were performed using the same 3 T General Electric Signa HDxT MRI (General Electric, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, USA) right-handed scanner using a multichannel head and neck coil at baseline, 6 and 12 months following the discontinuation of natalizumab therapy."

The patients had clinical assessments at baseline, 3, 6 and 12 months which is more frequent than typical follow-up for stable MS patients in usual care. They also had unscheduled visits for relapses and MRIs at baseline, 6 and 12 months. This follow-up protocol is more intensive than routine care.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Relevant quotes:
"The primary objective of this study was to compare two modes of natalizumab cessation interventions: immediate discontinuation (IDG) versus a TG approach as measured by serial MRI and number of relapses during a 12-month period in patients treated with natalizumab for at least 24 months."
"The classification of hyperintense T2 and hypointense T1-lesion evolution into several groups of increases such as new/enlarging was obtained. All number and activity analysis were performed at time points 0, 6 and 12 months after discontinuation of infusion."

The primary outcomes were relapses and MRI disease activity, which are clinically meaningful and routinely assessed in usual care. The MRI analysis was more detailed than usual care, but overall the primary outcomes are still relevant to the study's target population.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Relevant quote:
"The clear explanation of the benefit seen in our study when comparing the TG versus IDG is not fully understood. Recent data from a large retrospective multicenter experience suggest that extending the interval between natalizumab infusions may provide similar efficacy as compared to the monthly infusions, but with an increased safety profile."

The study does not explicitly state that an intention-to-treat analysis was used. However, no mention is made of excluding any randomized participants from the analysis, so it appears that all available data was used. More details on handling of missing data would be needed to fully assess this domain.
Score: [4]
original_llm_message:
Eligibility:
Relevant quotes:
"Fifty patients with relapsing MS, followed at the Jacobs MS Center for Treatment and Research, Department of Neurology, University at Buffalo, Buffalo New York, USA, were enrolled in this study. Inclusion criteria consisted of: a diagnosis of relapsing MS according to McDonald criteria, being on natalizumab therapy for 24 months or longer, aged between 18 and 65 years and an EDSS score of ≤7.0."
"Candidates were excluded from the study if active disease was identified at baseline per clinical (presence of a relapse during the previous 30 days) and/or MRI evaluation (active gadolinium (Gd)-enhancing lesions)."

The trial had fairly strict eligibility criteria, including requiring a confirmed diagnosis of relapsing MS, being on natalizumab for at least 24 months, having an EDSS score ≤7.0, and not having active disease at baseline. These criteria are more restrictive than the typical MS population that would receive natalizumab in usual care. However, some criteria like the diagnosis of relapsing MS and use of natalizumab are still in line with the trial's target population.
Score: [2]

Recruitment:
Relevant quotes:
"Fifty patients with relapsing MS, followed at the Jacobs MS Center for Treatment and Research, Department of Neurology, University at Buffalo, Buffalo New York, USA, were enrolled in this study."

All patients were recruited from a single MS center, rather than from multiple centers or community clinics as would be more representative of usual care. This limits the generalizability of the trial results.
Score: [2] 

Setting:
Relevant quote:
"Fifty patients with relapsing MS, followed at the Jacobs MS Center for Treatment and Research, Department of Neurology, University at Buffalo, Buffalo New York, USA, were enrolled in this study."

The trial was conducted at a single academic MS center in the USA. This is a more specialized setting than the mix of community and academic centers that would manage and prescribe natalizumab for MS patients in usual care.
Score: [2]

Organization:
The full text does not provide sufficient details on the provider expertise or healthcare resources used to deliver the intervention, compared to what would be available in usual care. 
Score: [NA]

Flexibility (delivery):
Relevant quotes:
"IDG: Patients who discontinued natalizumab therapy at once and initiated another DMT (interferon, GA therapy or an oral DMT: fingolimod, dimethyl fumarate or teriflunomide) at 1–6 months following the last natalizumab infusion (1–2 months for the injectable DMTs and 3–6 months for the oral DMTs) and tapered group (TG): patients administered two additional natalizumab infusions, one at 6 weeks and one at 8 weeks (14 weeks from study entry)."

The trial protocol specified the timing and type of DMTs permitted after natalizumab discontinuation. This is a more rigid, less flexible approach than would be likely in usual care, where the choice and timing of switching to another DMT would be left up to the clinician's discretion based on the individual patient's situation.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (adherence):
The full text does not mention any measures to monitor or enforce patient adherence to the assigned intervention protocol. Adherence does not appear to be a major issue though, since the interventions mainly involved the timing of DMT administration by clinicians.
Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:
Relevant quotes:
"Clinical assessments were performed at baseline, 3, 6 and 12 months postdiscontinuation (counted from the last natalizumab infusion, as per protocol)."
"A physical examination and neurological assessment was administered at baseline, 3, 6 and 12 months postdiscontinuation (counted from the last natalizumab infusion, as per the unscheduled visits due to relapses (within 3–5 days of any new symptom development)."
"Standardised MRI were performed using the same 3 T General Electric Signa HDxT MRI (General Electric, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, USA) right-handed scanner using a multichannel head and neck coil at baseline, 6 and 12 months following the discontinuation of natalizumab therapy."

The patients had clinical assessments at baseline, 3, 6 and 12 months which is more frequent than typical follow-up for stable MS patients in usual care. They also had unscheduled visits for relapses and MRIs at baseline, 6 and 12 months. This follow-up protocol is more intensive than routine care.

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Eligible participants were excluded from the study if they were already engaged in a formal exercise program lasting >30 minutes twice per week, experienced an exacerbation within the past 4 weeks, had their MS immunomodulation medications altered in the previous 4 weeks or during the trial period, or declined to be randomly allocated."
2. "Ethical approval was obtained through the University of Queensland Institutional Human Research Ethics Committee and the Multiple Sclerosis New South Wales Ethics Review Board."

The trial had several exclusion criteria that differ from usual care, such as excluding those already in an exercise program, those with recent exacerbations or medication changes, and those unwilling to be randomized. Obtaining ethical approval from institutional committees is also not part of usual care. However, the criteria do not seem overly restrictive and are reasonable for conducting a trial safely and ethically in this population.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Community dwelling people with MS were recruited through the Multiple Sclerosis Society of New South Wales and South Australia. Inclusion criteria were the following: diagnosis of MS made by a neurologist, able to walk 10 meters with or without an aid within 2 minutes, no relapse of their MS in the past 4 weeks, and no other non-motor symptoms that could affect function in MS simultaneously."

Participants were recruited through MS societies, which differs somewhat from usual care. The inclusion criteria of diagnosis by a neurologist and ability to walk 10m in 2 minutes without relapse seem reasonable approximations of the MS population likely to receive this intervention in practice. No other major recruitment efforts outside of usual care are mentioned.

Score: [4]

Setting:

Relevant quotes:
1. "The group program was conducted at a local community center for six participants in each group."

The intervention was delivered in a local community center, which is a reasonable approximation of where such a group program would likely occur in usual care. No other details are provided to suggest the setting differed significantly from usual care.

Score: [4]

Organization:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Groups were led by a physiotherapist employed by the Multiple Sclerosis Society who received training to ensure a standard approach to intervention, intensity, and progression."
2. "Group participants were provided with an illustrated exercise booklet at the completion of the intervention based on their class program and were encouraged to continue this level of exercise during the 8-week follow-up period."

The intervention required a physiotherapist from the MS Society who received additional training to standardize the program. Participants also received an illustrated exercise booklet, which may go beyond what is typically available in usual care. These factors suggest some additional organizational resources were required.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Exercises were aimed at improving gait speed, endurance, and balance. They were individualized, specific, and progressed in load, and performed at a moderate to high intensity."
2. "Guidelines were provided to physiotherapists and participants for exercises to be adapted and progressed to suit individual functional ability via increasing repetitions, amplitude of movement, speed of movement, and modifying base of support."

The exercises had a general aim and intensity, but were individualized and could be adapted and progressed based on the participant's ability. Guidelines were provided to physiotherapists, but they had flexibility in tailoring the exercises. This represents a balance between standardization and individualization.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants in both groups were encouraged to work at a pace which they could sustain for 6 minutes, but could rest if they felt fatigue, or had a perceived exertion of greater than 7/10 on the modified Borg scale."
2. "Participants in both groups were encouraged to maintain their usual activity levels and engagement in any other exercise throughout the trial, with any variation self-reported to the treating physiotherapist."

Participants were encouraged to sustain the target pace for 6 minutes but could rest if fatigued. They were encouraged to maintain usual activity levels but self-report any variations. This represents a pragmatic approach without strict adherence monitoring or requirements.

Score: [4]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
1. "Participants attended a local community center to complete all assessments at pre-intervention (week 0), post-intervention (week 8), and at follow-up (week 16)."
2. "Two baseline assessments were conducted 8 weeks apart to evaluate the stability of each presentation, with presentation considered stable if there was no significant difference between baseline assessments."

Follow-up assessments were conducted at the community center at 8 weeks post-intervention and again 8 weeks later. Two baseline assessments 8 weeks apart were done to establish stability. This follow-up is more extensive than typical usual care.

Score: [3]

Primary outcome:

Relevant quote:
1. "The primary outcome measure was gait speed, measured using the 10-meter walk test."

Gait speed, measured by the 10-meter walk test, is a clinically relevant outcome that would be feasible to assess in usual care. It directly measures an important functional outcome for patients.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:

No specific quotes relevant to the primary analysis were found in the full text. There is insufficient information provided to determine how pragmatic or explanatory the analysis approach was.

Score: [NA]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
1) "Male fans of two ice hockey teams (35–65 yr; body mass index ≤28 kg·m−2) located in Ontario (Canada) were randomized to intervention (Hockey FIT) or comparator (wait-list control). Hockey FIT included a 12-week active phase including provision of dietary information, practice of behavior change techniques, and safe exercise sessions plus incremental pedometer walking)"
2) "A sample size calculation for the definitive RCT was based on a 5% difference in weight loss between intervention and comparator at 12 months (20). Assuming an SD of 19.9%, 80% power, a 0.05 two-sided significance level, and a conservative 25% loss to follow-up estimate, 335 men in each arm (670 total) would be required."

The eligibility criteria are fairly pragmatic, including a broad age range (35-65) and BMI cutoff (≤28) that would likely capture a significant portion of male hockey fans. The trial also recruited from two different sites. However, the BMI cutoff and focus only on male fans make the eligibility criteria slightly more restrictive than a fully pragmatic trial. 
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
1) "Recruitment occurred using a variety of methods (e.g., hockey team e-mail blasts and social media accounts, study Web site (http://hockeyfansintraining.org/), posters, traditional media advertisements, word of mouth, direct contact at team arena). Eligible participants were male 35–65 yr old with a BMI of ≥28 kg·m−2 and met PA safety requirements (i.e., no risk indicated by the Physical Activity Readiness Questionnaire [36] or clearance from a health care provider)."

The trial used a variety of recruitment methods including team email lists, social media, a study website, posters, traditional media ads, word of mouth, and direct contact at arenas. While using multiple methods is pragmatic, some of these methods like a study website and media ads go beyond what would typically be used in usual care. The trial also required PAR-Q or physician clearance which is an extra step.
Score: [3]

Setting:
Quotes: 
1) "Eighty male fans of two ice hockey teams from two cities in Canada (London and Sarnia) were recruited and randomized to either intervention (Hockey FIT) or comparator (wait-list control)."

The trial was conducted with fans of two ice hockey teams in two Canadian cities. This is a fairly narrow setting that may limit generalizability. A fully pragmatic trial would likely include more diverse sites.
Score: [2] 

Organization:
Quotes:
1) "Hockey FIT coaches (coach to participant ratio 2:20) from the central research team (see Gill et al. [14] for information on coach background and training). Program sessions comprised the following: 1) classroom-based teaching of behavior change techniques and simple information sharing on PA and healthy eating, delivered via presentation, participant interaction, and mutual learning, and 2) exercise sessions where men performed aerobic, strength, and flexibility exercises, incorporating their passion for hockey off the ice."
2) "Participants were encouraged to continue with their lifestyle prescriptions and sustain their behavior changes with the support of free-of-charge eHealth tools and HealtheSteps smartphone app providing tools to track and sustain PA (www.healthesteps.ca) and 2) Hockey FIT social network, a secure Web-based network tailored to each site and including only group members"

The trial required specialized Hockey FIT coaches to deliver the intervention in a 2:20 ratio. Specific eHealth tools and a social network were also provided to participants. This level of expertise and resources goes beyond what would typically be available in usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
1) "Program sessions comprised the following: 1) classroom-based teaching of behavior change techniques and simple information sharing on PA and healthy eating, delivered via presentation, participant interaction, and mutual learning, and 2) exercise sessions where men performed aerobic, strength, and flexibility exercises, incorporating their passion for hockey off the ice."

The intervention involved a structured program of classroom sessions and exercise sessions. While there was some flexibility in the participant interactions and exercises incorporating hockey, overall the program seems to have followed a defined protocol rather than allowing provider discretion as in usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: 
1) "One individual withdrew after randomization because he was displeased with allocation to the comparator group."

The text does not provide much information on flexibility of adherence. One participant withdrew after being randomized to the control group, but it's unclear if any adherence metrics were used to exclude participants. There is not enough information to assess this domain.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes:
1) "Measurement sessions were held at baseline and 12 wk (both groups) and 12 months (intervention group only)."
2) "At baseline, groups were balanced on most demographic and health history characteristics, as well as study outcomes. Mean (SD) BMI values (36.5 (6.0)) correspond to class II (39); on average, participants reported daily step counts corresponding to a low active lifestyle (i.e., 5000–7499 steps per day) (38), and most participants consumed fruit/vegetables less than three times per day (see Table 1)."

The intervention group had follow-up measurement sessions at 12 weeks and 12 months, while the control group only had a 12 week follow-up. This is more intensive than typical follow-up in usual care. The measurements included BMI, step counts, and fruit/vegetable consumption which also goes beyond routine data collection.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
1) "The full study protocol has been published elsewhere (14). Briefly, we conducted a pilot, pragmatic randomized controlled trial (pRCT; parallel groups, stratified by site) in Ontario, Canada. Eighty male fans of two ice hockey teams from two cities in Ontario (London and Sarnia) were recruited and randomized to either intervention (Hockey FIT) or comparator (wait-list control)."
2) "We analyzed outcome data to examine the potential effectiveness of the Hockey FIT program on the basis of an intent-to-treat approach. We examined differences between groups in mean weight loss at 12 wk using a linear mixed-effects model, including a random effect for the intervention group assignment (i.e., including those with missing follow-up data and regardless of compliance with the intervention) and adjusted for age and site."

The primary outcome was weight loss at 12 weeks, which is a clinically meaningful outcome of importance to participants. The data were analyzed using intent-to-treat, including those with missing data. This is a fairly pragmatic approach, though a truly pragmatic trial may have extended follow-up beyond 12 weeks.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: 
1) "We analyzed outcome data to examine the potential effectiveness of the Hockey FIT program on the basis of an intent-to-treat approach. We examined differences between groups in mean weight loss at 12 wk using a linear mixed-effects model, including a random effect for the intervention group assignment (i.e., including those with missing follow-up data and regardless of compliance with the intervention) and adjusted for age and site."

The primary analysis used an intent-to-treat approach including all participants regardless of adherence or missing follow-up data. This is consistent with a pragmatic approach aiming to understand the real-world effectiveness of the intervention.
Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
"156 pregnant women in their ≥ 37 week/s, who had cervical dilations of ≥ 4 cm and with two or more contractions in 10 minutes, were randomly divided into three groups at a university hospital in the suburbs of Sao Paulo, Brazil, in order to receive either acupressure treatment, a placebo or participate as part of a control group."
"The pregnant women in labor were allocated through a sequential list of random numbers in blocks of six patients generated using the program Excel® and they were distributed in three groups: acupressure (SP6), touch group (TG)/placebo and the control group (CG)."

The trial included pregnant women in labor at a single hospital in Sao Paulo, Brazil who were at least 37 weeks gestation with cervical dilation ≥4cm and having at least 2 contractions per 10 minutes. They were randomized into blocks of 6. This represents a fairly pragmatic approach, as these criteria are typical for women in active labor who would normally receive pain management. However, conducting the trial at a single center makes it somewhat less generalizable.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
"The pregnant women in labor were allocated through a sequential list of random numbers in blocks of six patients generated using the program Excel® and they were distributed in three groups: acupressure (SP6), touch group (TG)/placebo and the control group (CG)."

Pregnant women in active labor at the hospital were recruited and randomized into the three study groups using a computer-generated random number list. No additional recruitment efforts beyond those that would occur in routine care are described. This represents a very pragmatic approach.
Score: [5]  

Setting:
Quotes:
"156 pregnant women in their ≥ 37 week/s, who had cervical dilations of ≥ 4 cm and with two or more contractions in 10 minutes, were randomly divided into three groups at a university hospital in the suburbs of Sao Paulo, Brazil, in order to receive either acupressure treatment, a placebo or participate as part of a control group."

The trial was conducted at a single university hospital in Sao Paulo, Brazil. While this is a typical setting where pregnant women in labor would receive care, the fact that it was limited to a single center makes the setting more explanatory than pragmatic. Results may not generalize to other hospitals or settings.
Score: [3]

Organization:
Quotes:
"The researcher that was responsible for applying the acupressure went through 32 hours' worth of training. A child-cushioned electronic anthropometric scale was used to control and to put consistent pressure on the thumps until the researcher could apply such pressure for the SP6 and TG groups."
"The pregnant women in labor obtained normal obstetrical treatment. Where the study was carried out, the following was permitted: the presence of someone to accompany the pregnant lady, the use of methods other than drugs such as taking a shower, massages in the lower back region and breathing exercises as well as liberty of movement (in cases where this did not go against medical advice)."

The trial required that the acupressure practitioner receive 32 hours of specialized training and use a special device to standardize the pressure applied. This goes beyond what would typically be available in usual care. However, otherwise the women received usual obstetric care during labor, including non-pharmacological pain management techniques, presence of a support person, and freedom of movement when medically appropriate. On balance, the trial used a moderately pragmatic approach in terms of organization.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
"The acupressure was applied on the sanyinjiao point during the contractions for 20 minutes. Then the intensity of the pain was evaluated using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)."
"The researcher that was responsible for applying the acupressure went through 32 hours' worth of training. A child-cushioned electronic anthropometric scale was used to control and to put consistent pressure on the thumps until the researcher could apply such pressure for the SP6 and TG groups."

The intervention involved applying pressure to the SP6 acupuncture point for a fixed duration of 20 minutes, by a researcher with specialized training using a standardized amount of pressure. This represents an inflexible, protocol-driven approach to delivering the intervention. A more pragmatic design would allow flexibility for the practitioner to adjust the treatment as they saw fit.

Flexibility (adherence):
This domain is not applicable, as it relates to patient adherence. Once the women consented to participate, they received the full intervention (acupressure, touch, or usual care) from the practitioner. There was no adherence issue on the part of the participants.

Follow-up:
Quotes:
"The acupressure was applied on the sanyinjiao point during the contractions for 20 minutes. Then the intensity of the pain was evaluated using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)."
"VAS was used to evaluate the pain and for pre-developed questions. The women were able to classify their perception of the pain (Table 3)."

The main follow-up appears to have occurred immediately after the 20-minute acupressure intervention, when pain was assessed using the VAS scale. Table 3 shows VAS scores before treatment, at 20 minutes, and at 60 minutes. No long-term follow-up beyond the labor and delivery period is described. However, assessing pain shortly after the intervention is reasonable for this condition and setting. The approach to follow-up is moderately pragmatic.
Score: [3]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: 
"Objective: to analyze the effects of acupressure on the sanyinjiao point for pregnant women in labor at public maternity wards. Method: single-blind controlled clinical trial, randomly done employing a pragmatic profile. We selected 156 pregnant women in their ≥ 37 week/s, who had cervical dilations of ≥ 4 cm and with two or more contractions in 10 minutes."
"VAS was used to evaluate the pain and for pre-developed questions. The women were able to classify their perception of the pain (Table 3)."

The primary outcome was pain during labor, assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), which is a commonly used and validated measure of pain. This is an outcome that is meaningful to women and providers. The VAS is simple to administer and interpret. Using the VAS as the primary outcome represents a pragmatic approach.
Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
"Analyzed (n = 52) (VAS60* and the Perception of pain after 60 mins) (n = 44)"
"*VAS60 = the Visual Analogical Scale, after 60 minutes of treatment"

The primary analysis included 52 of the 156 randomized participants (33%). It assessed pain at 60 minutes after the intervention using the VAS. No intention-to-treat approach including all randomized subjects was reported. The high rate of missing data and lack of ITT analysis represents an explanatory approach.
Score: [2]

"The pregnant women in labor were allocated through a sequential list of random numbers in blocks of six patients generated using the program Excel® and they were distributed in three groups: acupressure (SP6), touch group (TG)/placebo and the control group (CG)."

The trial included pregnant women in labor at a single hospital in Sao Paulo, Brazil who were at least 37 weeks gestation with cervical dilation ≥4cm and having at least 2 contractions per 10 minutes. They were randomized into blocks of 6. This represents a fairly pragmatic approach, as these criteria are typical for women in active labor who would normally receive pain management. However, conducting the trial at a single center makes it somewhat less generalizable.

llm_message:
Eligibility:

Relevant quotes:
"All potentially relevant patients (n = 291) were contacted for enrolment in the study from primary healthcare settings (n = 8) and the offices of private lung physicians (n = 6) in the Reykjavik capital area of Iceland."
"Enrolment ended when patients' registry in all possible clinical sites had been scanned. Data collection lasted from June 2009–March 2013."

The trial enrolled patients from primary healthcare settings and private lung physicians' offices in the Reykjavik capital area. It seems the eligibility criteria were quite broad, enrolling all potentially relevant patients from these sites until all possible sites had been scanned. This suggests the participants are fairly representative of the patients who would receive the intervention if it was part of usual care. However, the trial was limited to a specific geographic area (Reykjavik capital area) which makes it somewhat less pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:

Relevant quote:
"All potentially relevant patients (n = 291) were contacted for enrolment in the study from primary healthcare settings (n = 8) and the offices of private lung physicians (n = 6) in the Reykjavik capital area of Iceland."

Patients were recruited by contacting potentially relevant patients from primary healthcare settings and private lung physicians' offices. This approach leverages existing healthcare settings to identify patients, which is quite pragmatic. However, patients were actively contacted for enrollment rather than being recruited through usual appointments, and the recruitment was limited to a specific geographic area, so the approach is not maximally pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Setting:

Relevant quote:
"The treatment site was a clinical research centre located on a university-hospital campus. Enrolment ended when patients' registry in all possible clinical sites had been scanned. Data collection lasted from June 2009–March 2013."

The intervention was delivered at a single clinical research center located on a university-hospital campus. While this is a real-world clinical setting, using a single center makes the trial less pragmatic than if it had been delivered across multiple centers. The pragmatic approach would be to deliver the intervention in the same varied settings where it would be implemented in usual care.

Score: [3]

Organization:

There are no clear statements about differences in organization between the intervention and usual care. The full text does not provide enough information to assess this domain.

Score: [NA]

Flexibility (delivery):

Relevant quote:
"The intervention was an addition to traditional health care which the control group received. Traditional health care refers to services provided by general practitioners at primary health care centres and visits to lung physicians based on referral from general practitioners or self-initiated appointments."

The intervention was delivered as an addition to usual care, allowing flexibility for the control group to receive usual care. However, there are no details on if the delivery of the intervention itself was flexible or strictly protocolized. There is not enough information to fully assess flexibility of intervention delivery.

Score: [NA]

Flexibility (adherence):

There are no clear statements about measures to ensure or monitor participant adherence to the intervention. The full text does not provide enough information to assess this domain.

Score: [NA]

Follow-up:

Relevant quotes:
"The control group received usual care."
"Data collection lasted from June 2009–March 2013."

The control group received usual care, suggesting follow-up procedures were not more intense than usual care. Data collection occurred over an extended period from 2009-2013, but it's unclear if this involved more frequent follow-up than usual care. There is not quite enough information to determine if follow-up was different than usual care.

Score: [NA] 

Primary outcome:

Relevant quote:
"The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a partnership-based self-management programme for patients with mild and moderate COPD. The intervention was provided for 6 months with a subsequent follow-up for additional 6 months."

The primary outcome appears to be evaluating the effectiveness of the self-management program on COPD patients, which seems like an outcome that would be meaningful to patients. Assessing effectiveness at 6 months with an additional 6 month follow-up also seems like a reasonably pragmatic timeframe. However, without more details on exactly how effectiveness was measured, it's difficult to fully assess if the outcome measures were maximally pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Primary analysis:

Relevant quote:
"Intention-to-treat analysis was not carried out."

The study did not use an intent-to-treat approach, which is the most pragmatic approach to analysis. Instead, it seems only available data was analyzed, without explicitly stating the analysis approach. Lack of intent-to-treat analysis makes the analysis less pragmatic.

Score: [2]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility criteria

Relevant quotes:
"Objective To determine whether routine review by telephone of patients with asthma improves access and is a good alternative to face to face reviews in general practices."
"Patients were randomised to either telephone review or face to face consultation with the asthma nurse."

The trial aimed to determine if telephone consultations were a good alternative to face-to-face reviews for asthma patients in general practices. Patients were randomized to either telephone or face-to-face consultation with an asthma nurse. The eligibility criteria seem to be simply having asthma and being a patient at the participating general practices, which is likely very similar to the patients who would receive this intervention if implemented in usual care. No additional inclusion/exclusion criteria are mentioned that would make the participants different from usual care.

Score: [4]

2. Recruitment

Relevant quotes:
"Recruitment—All four general practices that took part in the study had nurses who were trained and experienced in providing proactive asthma care (table 1). From their computerised records the practices identified adults (>18 years) who had asked for a bronchodilator inhaler prescription in the previ-"

Patients were recruited from four general practices that took part in the study. The practices used their computerized records to identify adults prescribed bronchodilator inhalers in a recent time period. This recruitment approach of using electronic records to identify potentially eligible patients is likely very similar to how patients would be identified for asthma review in usual care.

Score: [5] 

3. Setting

Relevant quote:
"Setting Four general practices in England."

The trial was conducted in four general practices in England. Assuming the intent is for the intervention to be applicable to typical general practices, this is the same setting as where the results would be applied.

Score: [5]

4. Organization

Relevant quotes:
"Patients were randomised to either telephone review or face to face consultation with the asthma nurse."
"Nurses arranged any follow up consultations (whether in the surgery or by telephone) they deemed clinically necessary. Patients were free to arrange any consultations they wished."

The intervention involved having asthma nurses conduct the reviews, either by telephone or face-to-face. Nurses could arrange follow-up consultations as clinically needed, and patients could also arrange additional consultations if desired. This set-up does not require any additional resources or changes in care organization compared to usual care.

Score: [5]

5. Flexibility (delivery)

Relevant quotes:
"Nurses arranged any follow up consultations (whether in the surgery or by telephone) they deemed clinically necessary."
"Telephone consultations are safe alternatives in the triage of requests for same day appointments."

The nurses had flexibility in arranging follow-up consultations by telephone or in-person as they felt was clinically needed. The discussion also notes that telephone consultations are considered safe alternatives for triaging same-day appointment requests in usual care. This suggests the intervention delivery had similar flexibility to usual care.

Score: [4]

6. Flexibility (adherence)

There are no relevant quotes about measures to ensure or monitor patient adherence to the intervention protocols. The patients were not required to adhere to any particular behaviors. This domain does not seem applicable for this trial.

Score: [NA] 

7. Follow-up

Relevant quotes:
"Nurses arranged any follow up consultations (whether in the surgery or by telephone) they deemed clinically necessary. Patients were free to arrange any consultations they wished."
"A large US trial that compared normal clinic visits with a mix of face to face consultations and telephone reviews (the recommended interval for clinic visits was doubled and three telephone reviews took place in the intervening period) showed that telephone review has the potential to reduce morbidity, use of medication, and use of the health service in patients with a range of chronic disorders."

Nurses could arrange follow-up consultations as clinically indicated, with patients also free to schedule visits as desired. The discussion mentions another trial that had telephone reviews between in-person visits at double the usual interval. However, there is no indication that the follow-up in this study differed from usual care.

Score: [4]

8. Primary outcome

Relevant quotes:
"Main outcome measures Primary outcome measures were the proportion of participants who were reviewed within three months of randomisation and disease specific quality of life, as measured by the Juniper mini asthma quality of life questionnaire."

The primary outcomes were 1) the proportion of patients reviewed within 3 months and 2) asthma-related quality of life measured by a standard questionnaire. The first outcome, whether patients actually received their review, is directly relevant to patients and providers. Quality of life is also a patient-centered outcome. The Juniper mini-AQLQ is a validated questionnaire but may not be used in all usual care.

Score: [4]

9. Primary analysis

Relevant quotes:
"Sample size and statistical methods—An 80% power, at the 5% significance level (two tailed test), of detecting a 20% difference in the proportion of patients reviewed"
"To measure asthma morbidity we used the "short Q," a validated score incorporating three questions recommended by the Royal College of Physicians as outcome indicators for routine use in asthma care."

The sample size calculation and statistical analysis are not described in much detail. However, they aimed to detect a 20% difference in proportion of patients reviewed, analyzed the "short Q" morbidity score, and used nursing care satisfaction questionnaires. There is no mention of excluding any participants from analysis for protocol non-adherence. The limited information provided is consistent with an intent-to-treat approach.

Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
"Exclusions were: unstabilised concomitant disease, awaiting major surgery and inability to complete questionnaires unaided."
"Ninety-two per cent (83/90) of patient under NLC attended all five clinic sessions, with a mean total consultation time of 111 min compared to 85% (77/91) of the RLC group who had a mean total consultation time of 71 min."

The trial had some exclusion criteria that would not be present in usual care, such as inability to complete questionnaires unaided. However, the exclusion criteria were not overly restrictive and a high percentage of patients in both groups attended all clinic visits, suggesting the participants were fairly representative of typical rheumatoid arthritis patients. The eligibility criteria lean more pragmatic than explanatory.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
"The inclusion criteria were: a positive diagnosis of RA (1987 American College of Rheumatology (ACR) criteria); 18 years or older and the ability to complete questionnaires unaided."

The trial recruited rheumatoid arthritis patients meeting the 1987 ACR criteria who were 18 or older and could complete questionnaires. This matches how patients would be recruited in usual rheumatology care. No additional recruitment efforts beyond usual care are mentioned.
Score: [5]  

Setting:
Quotes:
"This study required three practitioners at each centre; a CNS, a rheumatologist and a blind independent assessor."
"Nine CNS and 10 rheumatologists delivered the interventions. The CNS had a median experience of 10 years in their current post while the rheumatologists had a median of 9 years at consultant level."

The trial was conducted at multiple rheumatology centers by experienced clinical nurse specialists and rheumatologists. This closely matches the usual care setting for treating rheumatoid arthritis patients in the UK.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes:
"The CNS have experience in running nurse-led clinics and usually have a postgraduate qualification in rheumatology nursing and/or prescribing. Independent assessors were health professionals trained to perform joint counts and calculating the DAS28."

The trial made use of existing experienced clinical nurse specialists who run nurse-led clinics as part of their usual roles. Independent assessors were health professionals who received training on joint counts and disease activity assessment, which goes somewhat beyond usual care.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
"Nine CNS and 10 rheumatologists delivered the interventions."
"When patients arrived at the clinic, the independent assessor performed 'joint counts' for DAS28 and then oversaw the completion of self-reported pain visual analogue scale (pain-VAS), fatigue-VAS and duration of morning stiffness. The patients were then given questionnaires in 'freepost' return envelopes before consultation with their allocated practitioner."

The interventions were delivered by the patients' usual rheumatologists and clinical nurse specialists, suggesting flexibility in delivery. However, the trial protocol dictated the timing and types of assessments administered before the consultation.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
There are no quotes related to measures to ensure or monitor patient adherence to the intervention. The full text does not provide enough information to assess flexibility of adherence.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes:
"Ninety-two per cent (83/90) of patient under NLC attended all five clinic sessions, with a mean total consultation time of 111 min compared to 85% (77/91) of the RLC group who had a mean total consultation time of 71 min."
"Available cases for baseline PP analysis (n=88)"

Patients attended clinic visits that were part of the trial protocol, with high attendance rates in both groups over the 12-month period. This represents a more intensive follow-up schedule than would be typical in usual care.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
"The primary outcome was DAS28 and secondary outcomes were pain severity (pain-VAS), fatigue (fatigue-VAS) and duration of morning stiffness measured at each study visit. Other secondary outcome measures were at baseline, weeks 26 and 52: RA quality of life; health assessment questionnaire disability index; hospital anxiety and depression scale; arthritis self-efficacy scale; and Leeds satisfaction questionnaire (LSQ)."

The primary outcome of rheumatoid arthritis disease activity (DAS28) is highly relevant to patients. Secondary outcomes like pain, fatigue, disability, and quality of life are also important to patients. The measures used, such as DAS28 and the Health Assessment Questionnaire, are routinely collected in rheumatology care, though some of the other measures may be less commonly used.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
"Analysis followed per-protocol (PP) and intention-to-treat (ITT) approaches."
"The former was based on evaluation of all participants who completed the five treatment sessions and focused on a complete case analysis; the latter was based on evaluation of all trial participants as allocated. For the ITT approach, missing data were imputed via multiple imputation using chained equations; 20 imputed datasets were computed on guidance that the number needed should approximate the percentage of incomplete cases."

The trial conducted both per-protocol and intention-to-treat analyses. For the ITT analysis, missing data were imputed, allowing all randomized participants to be included. This is a pragmatic approach, though the per-protocol analysis is more explanatory.
Score: [4]
original_llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
"Exclusions were: unstabilised concomitant disease, awaiting major surgery and inability to complete questionnaires unaided."
"Ninety-two per cent (83/90) of patient under NLC attended all five clinic sessions, with a mean total consultation time of 111 min compared to 85% (77/91) of the RLC group who had a mean total consultation time of 71 min."

The trial had some exclusion criteria that would not be present in usual care, such as inability to complete questionnaires unaided. However, the exclusion criteria were not overly restrictive and a high percentage of patients in both groups attended all clinic visits, suggesting the participants were fairly representative of typical rheumatoid arthritis patients. The eligibility criteria lean more pragmatic than explanatory.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
"The inclusion criteria were: a positive diagnosis of RA (1987 American College of Rheumatology (ACR) criteria); 18 years or older and the ability to complete questionnaires unaided."

The trial recruited rheumatoid arthritis patients meeting the 1987 ACR criteria who were 18 or older and could complete questionnaires. This matches how patients would be recruited in usual rheumatology care. No additional recruitment efforts beyond usual care are mentioned.
Score: [5]  

Setting:
Quotes:
"This study required three practitioners at each centre; a CNS, a rheumatologist and a blind independent assessor."
"Nine CNS and 10 rheumatologists delivered the interventions. The CNS had a median experience of 10 years in their current post while the rheumatologists had a median of 9 years at consultant level."

The trial was conducted at multiple rheumatology centers by experienced clinical nurse specialists and rheumatologists. This closely matches the usual care setting for treating rheumatoid arthritis patients in the UK.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes:
"The CNS have experience in running nurse-led clinics and usually have a postgraduate qualification in rheumatology nursing and/or prescribing. Independent assessors were health professionals trained to perform joint counts and calculating the DAS28."

The trial made use of existing experienced clinical nurse specialists who run nurse-led clinics as part of their usual roles. Independent assessors were health professionals who received training on joint counts and disease activity assessment, which goes somewhat beyond usual care.

The patients were then given questionnaires in 'freepost' return envelopes before consultation with their allocated practitioner."

The interventions were delivered by the patients' usual rheumatologists and clinical nurse specialists, suggesting flexibility in delivery. However, the trial protocol dictated the timing and types of assessments administered before the consultation.

llm_message:
1. Eligibility criteria

Relevant quotes:
"Participants comprised 50.6% Indigenous Australians and 60.8% had established CVD. At baseline, use of combination treatment was 50.1%."
"Participants were excluded if they had a usual clinic BP of <130/80mmHg and were not taking any BP lowering medications."

The trial included a broad population of Indigenous Australians and those with established CVD, who would likely be candidates for the polypill intervention in usual care. However, those with BP already controlled without medications were excluded, which is a more explanatory approach. Overall, the eligibility criteria were moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

2. Recruitment

Relevant quotes:
"We conducted a randomized, open-label trial involving 623 participants from Australian general practices."
"The study failed to recruit the numbers of participants originally planned as a result of limited resources and was therefore under-powered to demonstrate significant differences in BP and cholesterol."

Participants were recruited from general practices, which is a pragmatic approach. However, recruitment was limited by resources leading to under-enrollment. The full text does not provide further details on specific recruitment methods used.

Score: [4]

3. Setting

Relevant quote:
"We conducted a randomized, open-label trial involving 623 participants from Australian general practices."

The trial was conducted in Australian general practices, which is the same setting in which the polypill intervention would be used in usual care. This represents a very pragmatic approach to setting.

Score: [5]

4. Organization

Relevant quotes:
"All participants were reviewed one month post-randomization and at three monthly intervals thereafter."
"Participants attended the primary healthcare centres for trial assessments at randomization and 12 month intervals thereafter."

The trial involved 3-monthly visits which go beyond what would typically occur in usual primary care. Conducting the trial assessments at the primary healthcare centers themselves is pragmatic. Overall, the trial used a moderately pragmatic approach in terms of organization.

Score: [3]

5. Flexibility (delivery)

Relevant quote:
"The polypill was dispensed without charge at Indigenous health services operating under the Section 100 scheme of the National Health Act."

Dispensing the polypill without charge through Indigenous health services represents a pragmatic approach that fits with how the intervention would be delivered in usual care for this population. The full text does not describe any other measures to monitor or restrict flexibility of intervention delivery.

Score: [4]

6. Flexibility (adherence)

Relevant quote:
"Patients may adopt strategies to reduce costs, including not filling prescriptions and omitting doses."

The text mentions that patients may adopt strategies to reduce costs by not filling prescriptions or omitting doses. This suggests that a pragmatic approach was taken, without measures to enforce adherence. However, not enough details are provided to fully assess flexibility of adherence.

Score: [NA] 

7. Follow-up

Relevant quotes:
"All participants were reviewed one month post-randomization and at three monthly intervals thereafter."
"Self-reported use of all medications was assessed at each visit, recorded at local centres on which medication was taken in the immediately preceding week."

Participants were followed up every 3 months, which is more frequent than typical for usual care. Medication use was self-reported at each visit. Overall, follow-up was more intensive than usual care, representing a more explanatory approach.

Score: [2]

8. Primary outcome

Relevant quotes:
"Primary outcomes were self-reported use of indicated combination treatment (antiplatelet, statin and ≥2 BP lowering therapies for ≥4 of the previous seven days) at study end; and changes in systolic BP and total cholesterol from baseline to study end."

The primary outcomes of self-reported medication use and changes in BP/cholesterol are relevant to patients and consistent with what would be measured in usual care. Relying on self-report is pragmatic. Measuring the outcomes at study end rather than longer-term is more explanatory.

Score: [4]

9. Primary analysis

Relevant quote:
"All analyses were conducted on an intention-to-treat basis without imputation of missing data."

The trial used an intention-to-treat approach including all randomized participants, which is a pragmatic approach to analysis. There was no imputation of missing data, but this does not necessarily impact how pragmatic or explanatory the analysis was.

Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
"Of 1250 patients assessed for eligibility, 563 (45%) were eligible and 687 (55%) were ineligible (Figure 1). The most common reason for exclusion (>1 reason per patient possible) was that a patient had comorbidities that precluded surgery or anesthetic."
"These characteristics were similar to patients who refused consent (mean age, 68 years; 75% female). Ineligible patients tended to be older (mean age, 70 years) and there were slightly fewer females (72%) (eTable 1 in Supplement 2)."

The trial excluded a significant proportion (55%) of patients assessed for eligibility, with the most common reasons being comorbidities precluding surgery/anesthesia and older age. The eligible patients differed somewhat from the ineligible patients in terms of age and sex. This suggests the eligibility criteria were more stringent than what would be typical in usual care for patients with displaced proximal humerus fractures.

Score: [2]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
"192 [77%] were female, and 249 (99.6%) were white."
"The mean age of the trial participants was 66 years (range, 24-92 years)"

The trial recruited mostly white females with an average age of 66 years from orthopedic departments in the UK. While this may reflect the typical patient population with this condition, the very high proportion of white participants (99.6%) suggests recruitment was not as broadly representative as it would be in usual care.

Score: [3]

Setting:
Quotes:
"A pragmatic, multicenter, parallel-group, randomized clinical trial, the Proximal Fracture of the Humerus Evaluation by Randomization (PROFHER) trial, recruited 250 patients aged 16 years or older (mean age, 66 years [range, 24-92 years]; 192 [77%] were female; and 249 [99.6%] were white) who presented at the orthopedic departments of 32 acute UK National Health Service hospitals between September 2008 and April 2011 within 3 weeks after sustaining a displaced fracture of the proximal humerus involving the surgical neck."

The trial was conducted at orthopedic departments across 32 UK National Health Service hospitals, representing the typical setting where patients with this fracture would be treated. This supports a pragmatic approach.

Score: [4]

Organization:
Quotes:
"Standardized outpatient and community-based rehabilitation was provided to both groups."
"Physiotherapists (median of 4 sessions for each physiotherapist; IQR, 2-8 sessions) provided conservative treatment to both groups."

The trial provided standardized rehabilitation to both surgical and nonsurgical groups, delivered by physiotherapists. This matches how care would typically be organized for these patients in usual practice.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
"Surgeons experienced in these techniques performed the surgical procedures."
"Surgeons (median of 1 patient per surgeon; IQR, 1-3 patients) performed the surgical procedures."

The trial allowed flexibility in the surgical procedures, which were performed by experienced surgeons according to their usual techniques. Each surgeon treated a median of only 1 patient. This suggests delivery of the intervention had similar flexibility to usual care.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):
The full text does not provide any information on measures to ensure or monitor participant adherence to the assigned interventions.

Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:
Quotes:
"Patients were followed up at 2 years (up to April 2013) and 215 had complete follow-up data."
"The data for 231 patients (114 in surgical group and 117 in nonsurgical group) were included in the primary analysis."

The trial followed up patients at 2 years, which is a longer duration than typical for evaluating a fracture treatment. However, the follow-up did not seem to involve additional visits or data collection beyond what would be done in usual care. 215 of 250 patients (86%) had complete 2-year data.

Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
"The primary outcome was the Oxford Shoulder Score (OSS), which is a shoulder-specific outcome measure validated in a UK population."
"The OSS provides a total score based on the patient's subjective assessment of pain and function. It contains 12 items, each with 5 categories of response, and a range of total scores of 0 (worst outcome) to 48 (best outcome)."

The Oxford Shoulder Score is a patient-reported outcome measure specific to shoulder function and validated in the UK population. It assesses domains relevant to patients such as pain and function using a simple questionnaire. This supports a pragmatic approach to the primary outcome.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
"All analyses followed a prespecified analysis plan, endorsed by the data monitoring and ethics committee, and were performed using Stata version 12 (StataCorp). All analyses were on an intention-to-treat basis and included all randomized patients in the groups to which they were randomized."
"The primary analysis compared OSS data from the surgical and nonsurgical treatment groups over all 3 follow-up assessments (6, 12, and 24 months)."

The primary analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, including all randomized patients according to their assigned groups. Missing data were handled through use of multilevel modeling. No patients were excluded post-randomization. This reflects a pragmatic approach to the primary analysis.

Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
"Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham. Patients aged ≥65 years were identified by searches of computerised medical records and invited to participate if they were:"
"Patients were eligible to participate if they were: • community dwelling aged ≥65 years; • independently mobile (with or without a walking aid); and • physically able to take part in group exercise."
"Patients were excluded if they: • had experienced ≥3 falls in the previous year; • had unstable clinical conditions; • would be unable to follow instructions about exercising safely; or • were receiving palliative care."

The trial recruited participants aged 65 and over who were community-dwelling and independently mobile, which is likely similar to the population that would receive this intervention in usual care. However, they excluded those with 3 or more falls in the past year, unstable conditions, inability to follow exercise instructions, or receiving palliative care. These exclusions make the population somewhat less representative of those who would receive the intervention in usual care.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
"Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham."
"Patients aged ≥65 years were identified by searches of computerised medical records and invited to participate if they were:"

Practices were recruited through primary care research networks, and patients were identified through electronic medical record searches and invited to participate. This recruitment approach is more systematic and resource-intensive than what would occur in usual care, where patients would likely just be referred during routine visits. However, the medical record searches are still a relatively pragmatic approach compared to more explanatory methods like targeted mailings or media advertisements.

Score: [3]

Setting:
Quotes:
"Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham."

The trial was conducted in primary care practices in London, Nottingham, and Derby. This represents a fairly diverse, real-world setting where the intervention would be delivered in usual care. Conducting the trial in multiple cities increases the applicability. The only thing keeping this from being a 5 is that it's unclear if the specific practices are representative of the full spectrum that would offer the intervention in usual care.

Score: [4]

Organization:
Quotes:
"Exercise instructors were the home-based OEP arm, and postural stability instructors were the FaME arm."
"The cost per additional volunteer peer mentor time for the OEP was established by replacement cost methods using the human capital approach."

The intervention was delivered by exercise instructors in the OEP arm and postural stability instructors in the FaME arm, which differs from usual primary care. Volunteer peer mentors were also used to support the OEP arm participants. This represents a change from how the intervention would be delivered in usual care, so it is somewhat explanatory.

Score: [3] 

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
"Patients in the FaME arm received group exercise once a week for 12 weeks, and participants in the OEP arm received per protocol peer mentor support. Baseline characteristics of practices and participants are shown by arm in Table 1; treatment arms were well balanced."

The text does not provide many details on flexibility of intervention delivery. Patients in the FaME arm received weekly group exercise for a fixed 12 weeks, which suggests a fairly rigid schedule. The OEP arm included per-protocol peer mentor support, but the flexibility of this is unclear. Overall there is not enough information to fully judge flexibility of delivery.

Score: [NA]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes:
"Adherence was defined as the proportion of participants who reported reaching ≥150 minutes of MVPA per week. Physical activity was assessed using three validated questionnaires: Phone-FITT, the Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly (PASE), and the Community Healthy Activities Model Program for Seniors (CHAMPS). The primary outcome measure was the CHAMPS questionnaire."

Adherence was assessed using self-reported physical activity questionnaires, but no measures to enforce or encourage adherence are mentioned. Assessing adherence is somewhat explanatory, but not actively pushing for adherence or excluding non-adherers is more pragmatic. There is limited information to judge this domain.

Score: [3]

Follow-up:
Quotes:
"Follow-up assessments were carried out at 6, 12, 18, and 24 months after the end of the intervention period."
"The proportions reporting at least 150 minutes of MVPA per week rose from 40% (136/342) to 49% (95/193) in the FaME arm, 41% (150/362) to 43% (99/185) in the OEP arm, and 37.5% (150/400) to 38% (84/222) in the usual-care arm, 12 months after the end of the intervention."

Follow-up assessments were done at 6, 12, 18, and 24 months post-intervention, which is more frequent and longer than what would typically occur in usual care. The primary outcome of self-reported physical activity was assessed via questionnaires at these timepoints. This extended follow-up makes the trial more explanatory.

Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
"The proportions reporting at least 150 minutes of MVPA per week rose from 40% (136/342) to 49% (95/193) in the FaME arm, 41% (150/362) to 43% (99/185) in the OEP arm, and 37.5% (150/400) to 38% (84/222) in the usual-care arm, 12 months after the end of the intervention."

The primary outcome was the proportion of participants reporting at least 150 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per week on the CHAMPS questionnaire. This self-reported physical activity outcome is relevant and meaningful to participants. Using a validated questionnaire is how this might be assessed in usual care, though the CHAMPS questionnaire is a bit more detailed than what would typically be used. Overall this is a fairly pragmatic outcome.

Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
"All analyses were carried out on data from participants in the FaME arm: • assuming that those not returning relevant diaries had not undertaken any exercise during that 4-week period; and • omitting any participant who had not returned all six diaries."

The primary analysis used data from participants in the FaME arm, assuming non-returned diaries indicated no exercise and omitting participants missing any diaries. This is not a full intention-to-treat analysis, as it appears to exclude participants based on missing diary data. However, it's not clear if this is the primary analysis for the main outcome or just for a secondary adherence outcome. There is not quite enough information provided to determine how pragmatic the primary analysis is.

Score: [NA]
